Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Bradfield) (5.18)-The honourable member for Bendigo ( Mr Brumby), who has just treated the House to a long dissertation of the various elements of the Government's policies and why the Government needs to cut back expenditure, has missed the most salient fact of all. One of the key reasons why we are in our current difficult economic situation is that over four Budgets, despite the rapid economic improvement which took place after the breaking of the drought, and especially in the first two years of this Government as a result of the success of the Fraser Government's wage freeze, the breaking of the drought and a general improvement in our international terms of trade-elements which should have given the Government the opportunity to establish a sound economic base-no advantage was taken of those elements; so the opposite situation now prevails. Not only do we have a Treasurer ( Mr Keating) who talks about the country being a banana republic and a Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) who talks about us being in a state of war in economic terms; we have now had to listen to the honourable member for Bendigo suggesting that this legislation is essentially 'insignificant'-his word-in the context of the Government's budgetary policy. The honourable member for Bendigo and all Government members would do well to take heed of my words. Superannuitants, whether through the Defence Force retirement and death benefits program or through the Australian Public Service superannuation scheme, do not regard this legislation in any sense as insignificant. The Opposition accepts the need for all sections of the community to be prepared to tighten their belts, but this Government, particularly the Treasurer, is unable to set an appropriate example. Today in Question Time we saw how, time after time, the issue of the Treasurer's allowances was raisedMr Brumby-I take a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. This issue was raised a number of times before you took the chair. The Deputy Speaker then in the chair ruled that the matter was not pertinent to the debate. I fail to see how the question of travelling allowances, which are decided by the Remuneration Tribunal, has anything to do with the payment of Commonwealth superannuation pensions. I respectfully suggest that the honourable member is completely out of order. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs Darling) - The honourable member for Bradfield is out of order, and, I point out, not just in terms of relevance. Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. The essential ingredients of the legislation turn around two elements: Firstly, its impact on the Defence Force retirement benefits arrangements and, secondly, on the Public Service superannuation scheme. The Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme has for many years been one of the key elements which have made service in the Australian armed forces a career worthy of this nation and of the people who have contributed to it. It is an unfortunate fact that the honourable member for Corio ( Mr Scholes), when he was the defence spokesman for the then Opposition in 1983, gave a commitment that a Labor government would not cut the DFRB or DFRDB schemes. Since then, on no fewer than two occasions, fundamental changes have been made that will affect not only future recruitment to the armed Services but also, in a very real sense, those who have given their service to Australia and who have now retired and are, therefore, the least able in our community to defend their interests. Because of that, the Opposition believes that it is our prime responsibility to bring home to this House and to the Government that the way upon which it has entered into this set of arrangements leaves very much to be desired. I thought that in a Labor administration we had a government which believed in conciliation, arbitration, in taking through issues and in trying to seek consensus, which is the Prime Minister's favourite word. I find it extraordinary that the Treasurer in his Budget Statement simply put it down as holy writ that the 2 per cent deduction in pensions would take place, irrespective of the fact that it is the responsibility of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to make those determinations. The virtue of that system-it is a virtue that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations ( Mr Willis) tries to espouse time after time in this House-is that it gives all parties the opportunity to put forward their point of view. The fact of the matter is that no organisation, least of all the Federal Executive of the Armed Forces Federation of Australia or, to the best of my knowledge, the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, the Professional Officers Association and any union concerned with Public Service, has been given any opportunity to discuss this matter in advance of the budgetary decision or in the context of the conciliation and arbitration discussions which would normally precede a decision taken by the Commission to vary or reduce, wages and benefits by 2 per cent across the board, as proposed by the Government. In the armed forces context, the Government is saying that it wants to see the pension of returned service men and women, people who have given their service to Australia, reduced by $161.54 this year. That cost will compound to $2,031 over 10 years. That is calculated on a very generous basis-the assumption of a mere 5 per cent inflation rate. Since we have had nowhere near that rate in the four years of Labor Government, one could safely assume that while this Government remains in power the level of real loss of income to the DFRDB contributions-will be greater. I emphasise the word 'contributors'; it is a contributory scheme and the benefits have accrued from the contributions made over a quarter of a century by men and women who have helped finance this procedure as a means of ensuring some independence in retirement. There is nothing more damaging to any retiree under any scheme than not to know the basis upon which he can plan for his future. I do not think that is an unreasonable objective. I hope that all honourable members share it. However, the way in which the Government has gone about these amendments demonstrates yet again the fundamental weakness in taking one element of a problem and trying to shave costs and ignoring the others. I trust that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs ( Mr Holding), who is at the table and who has a wide knowledge of defence matters, would be aware that it costs some $lm to train an Air Force pilot. Yet in this grand gesture of cost saving by the Treasurer, in the context of the DFRDB proposals, the savings will be $4.7m in 1986-87 and $6.3m in 1987-88. I add that, in the context of the Public Service superannuation changes, the savings will be $7.9m in 1986-87 and $llm in 198788. That is on the basis of the 2 per cent discount. The point I wish to make is this: When our Services are definitely being bled, especially of their officer cadre, it seems pathetic in the extreme for the Government to say, with a great beating of its breast, that it is saving a miserable $4.7m when, as I said earlier, it costs $Im to train one pilot. In the past seven months there have been in excess of 562 male officer resignations. That applies to all three Services-the Navy, the Army and the Air Force. By any stretch of the imagination, the total cost of training 562 officers would be nothing less than $200m. Yet we see, gradually, perceptively and deliberately, a consistent eating away and a reduction in the conditions of service and the fringe benefits of the men and women who contribute to Australia's defence in our armed services. It is great in times of peace for a democracyas was the case in years past, and the years between 1918 and 1939 were no exception-to denigrate those men and women who have made that contribution. Something divides them from the rest of us, and it is simply this: In their decision to join the armed forces, they, in every sense of the term, put their lives on the line for our defence, to protect our freedom. Here we have a government turning on those people who have given their service, and retired or are about to retire from the armed forces, and saying: 'Thank you very much. We do not want you any more. We are now going to reduce your benefits, and we do not really care whether those benefits are so low that you then have to take the old age pension'. The same principle applies to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. I wonder how many members of this omniscient Government which knows so little about so much realise that whereas it is general folklore that the Commonwealth superannuation scheme is massively generous and better than anybody else's, 61.35 per cent of all retirees from the Commonwealth Public Service receive benefits through their sion scheme which are so low that they automatically qualify for some or all of the age pension. I simply put it to the Governmentbecause I honestly believe that it has not examined this fact-that proposal is simply increasing the number of superannuitants, whether it be under the DFRDB scheme or the Common'Yealth superannuation scheme, who will qualify for the age pension. I hope the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs ( Mr Holding), is an expert in such matters and can answer all these issues, whether with the advice of his experts or otherwise. I ask him seriously to tell the House whether, in the calculation of the alleged savings-I emphasise them again-approximately $4.7m in 1986-87 for the DFRDB and $7.9m for the same period for the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, the Department of Finance advised Ministers as to what the flow-on effect would be of going down this road, which would simply enable those at the bottom end of pen- the pension, whether Commonwealth superannuation or DFRDB, to qualify for access to the old age pension because they have broken through the minimum income level. In 1985-86, pension ceases to be paid when income reaches $218.60 per week or $11,367.20 per annum. Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: ZZZZZ
text: These statistics bear out clearly the errors which can be created by a government which is not prepared to look both vertically and laterally at the impact of its decisions. The most fundamental thing is that this Government has not had the courage in the last Budget to say to the Australian people: 'We are going to reduce significantly all old age pensions by 2 per cent'. But by its action today, by bringing to this House legislation which is going to hurt those least able to defend themselves, whether they be pensioners under the Defence Force retirement benefits scheme or under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, millions of pensioners throughout Australia will be saying: 'I wonder whether we can trust this Government again. Are we going to be the next people whose benefits will be cut, allegedly to save money?'. We are facing a government which, through its duplicity, and especially the duplicity of its Treasurer, has demonstrated that we have one law for the people and another law for members of the Labor Party.

Speaker: Mr IAN ROBINSON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Page) (5.35)-I rise to strongly support the Opposition's amendment in relation to the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill. The amendment proposes that the concern of the House be expressed at the Government's decision to alter the level of and to discount the Defence Force retirement benefits and the Defence Force retirement and death benefits before there is a proper determination in matters of this kind and before a national wage case has considered the proposal for a 2 per cent discounting in wages. The Bill imposes on superannuitants a burden greater than that being proposed for the community generally. Of course, it will come into effect before the issue of the equivalent discounting of wages is given consideration. I believe that the case put this afternoon by the Government, and put very weakly by two back benchers-the honourable member for Bendigo ( Mr Brumby) and the honourable member for Banks ( Mr Mountford)-obviously in the absence of any strong proposition by Government Ministers, reveals that this is just another attempt by stealth, through this Budget, to cut away from people their real rights. When we consider the position of superannuitants in the various categories, but particularly in the defence forces, we find that it is nothing more or less than the implementation by this Government of a philosophy to take away from the prudent section of the community with the express purpose, as indicated by those Government back benchers, of giving more to the less prudent sections of the community. I in no way suggest that the needy pensioner or the needy person in the welfare area should be deprived of any form of benefit, particularly not those who come well below the poverty line. But here we have a different issue entirely. This issue is one of the realities, and the reality on this score is that of breaking a promise-a promise made by the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) back in 1983-that there would be no cuts in superannuation and no cuts in benefits for the members of the defence forces and that the Government would look after their interests. Mr Adermann-Yes, they broke that promise.

Speaker: Mr IAN ROBINSON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: They have not done it. As the honourable member for Fairfax has said, they have broken that promise and they are proceeding to break more and more promises. The diabolical factor in all of this-it is apparently one about which the Government is not the least bit concerned-is the fall in the strength of the armed Services. The resignations referred to by Opposition speakers this afternoon show clearly that the defence Services are suffering severely because of the lack of incentive for those who would want to serve in any of the branches of the armed Services. Mr Adermann-Destroying their morale.

Speaker: Mr IAN ROBINSON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The honourable member for Fairfax is dead right. It is destroying their morale. That morale is absolutely essential if we are to maintain at a reasonable strength the personnel required for an effective defence policy and for an effective armed service in this country, in whichever branch it happens to be. What is not being admitted by the Government in this debate is simply that part of the reward promised to those who entered the Services, when they sought to enlist, was that they would receive certain benefits. This is one of those benefits. The Government is quickly endeavouring to chisel away at these benefits, because it does not have an interest in the maintenance of an effective armed service for this country. The Government's acceptance of the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, in fact its attitude on the whole question of defence, is such that this measure is clearly much more a matter of philosophy than a matter of Budget strategy. The amount that is being saved in this legislation is very small. In regard to total Budget outlays, these alterations will reduce the Government's commitment in this financial year by only $12.6m and in the next financial year by $17.3m-a very small amount indeed. But its effect on beneficiaries and on the morale of those in the various Services is quite different. Of course, the effect is demonstrable. Let us compare it to the circumstances that exist either in the private sector or in other sectors of government. By chiselling away at this particular element we are discouraging those who have as their objective, as part of the maintenance of their role, a degree of self-reliance in the future. When they see that self-reliance disappearing, what do they do? They look at their personal situation and say 'Is it worth it?' and they opt to leave. This legislation gives a further them. impetus to the fall-off in those areas of defence which are so important to this nation and which will be increasingly important in the years ahead. The honourable member for MCPherson ( Mr White) emphasised this point. He is one who has had vast experience in this field. He pointed out very effectively this afternoon the dire consequences of this kind of reduction in recognition of service to the country, whether it be in the Public Service or in the defence forces. What has been lost sight of, undoubtedly, is that by reducing the benefits we merely push many of these people further into the area of social welfare. This, I believe, is a tragic approach by any government that wants to encourage people to have greater reliance on their own resources in their retirement. If there is to be a trend in this direction, let us think of the consequences. It means that people will say: 'Is it worthwhile to contribute to a superannuation fund? Is it worthwhile to try to provide for one's retirement?'. The answer, obviously, is that, if this is to be the Government's policy in future and if this is a lead towards its attitudes, it is contrary even to trade union policy. I do not know what the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs ( Mr Hurford), who represents the Minister for Finance and who is at the table, will tell us about that. But on the one hand we have a very great demand from the trade union movement for an expansion of superannuation, for an all-embracing system of superannuation in this country, and, on the other, in this case we are reducing a genuine, proper and sensibly based superannuation provision. I am amazed that the honourable member for Bendigo this afternoon could cite percentage bases when making comparisons about existing benefits. In other words, he put to this House that, even with the cut in superannuation benefit, there were still people on full salaries who, in percentage terms, were receiving less. What utter humbug! What rubbish! It is rubbish because one cannot refer to percentages when one makes that comparison. Of course, on a percentage basis, there would be people receiving lower salaries. Is that any surprise? Mr Hollis-Don't ask me. I didn't make the speech.

Speaker: Mr IAN ROBINSON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: The honourable member is the only Governmentback bencher in the House at the moment who can back up his colleague. There are two Ministers at the table. I do not know whether we will hear from them, but I hope that we will hear from one of Mr MCGauran-it was typical of the honourable member for Bendigo.

Speaker: Mr IAN ROBINSON
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Obviously, the honourable member for Bendigo is an academic. At least, he expresses, on behalf of his back bench colleagues, an academic attitude on all matters on which he speaks. His attitude this afternoon was certainly academic, because the comparisons he made just do not hold water. If one uses merely the percentage approach, quite obviously one is fooling people who deserve a better coverage of information from the Government about what is actually being done. We know that the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, in his second reading speech, indicated to us that this measure was being implemented on the premise that because the automatic increases in superannuation were based on certain weighted averages-on the average consumer price index for the six capital cities-it was pretty generous. But let us look at the real facts. We are talking about an increase, that would have applied, in an average superannuation situation, of about $962 a year. This proposal cuts that amount back to $753 a year, which represents $4 a week. If one relates that to present day living costs-and that is the issue-$4 a week is a very substantial erosion of benefit for those people who are receiving a superannuation benefit. It is sheer humbug for honourable members to compare it on a percentage basis with actual wages, simply because wages run at a very much higher level than does superannuation, and understandably so. Superannuation, in the main, is a retirement benefit. Let us turn to one other aspect that has not been mentioned much in this debate. I draw the attention of the House to what this Government has done to superannuation generally since it came to office, despite its promises in 1983. I refer to the determinations for commutation, which very greatly reduced the rights of the individual, and the introduction of hefty tax on superannuation. We are now dealing with a reduction in the superannuation levels. So what is the Government's intention? There is no doubt as to what its intention is. It would rather see everyone on social welfare, and have no superannuation schemes or have superannuation schemes that merely equate with social welfare. That, surely, destroys every incentive and initiative and is an appalling approach by any government, let alone a neo-socialist government of the sort that is occupying the treasury bench at present. In conclusion, I remind the House that the amendment moved by the Opposition to the motion for the second reading is that the Opposition, whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, expresses great concern at the way in which this measure has been introduced, the basis that has been applied for its introduction, and the decision not to allow a proper approach by way of reference to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal before making the determination. I hope that the community will recognise how shabbily superannuitants have been treated by this Government.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: ZZZZZ
text: Adelaide-Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs) (5.50)-ln closing the debate on the second reading, I want to thank all the members who have taken part. Some, of course, made more worthwhile contributions than others. The Government rejects the second reading amendment from the Opposition for a number of very good reasons. The first part of the amendment reads: The House(I) expresses its concern that the level of discounting of superannuation . . . imposed by the legislation has not yet been proposed in a National Wage Case, let alone given effect by a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Leader of the National Party of Australia ( Mr Sinclair), who I understand led for the Opposition-I apologise that I was not able to be here at the time-apparently made some reference to page 10 of the Budget Speech and quoted the part that states: . . . the Government will argue to the Arbitration Commission that the proposed increase in wages be cut by 2 per cent. The honourable member then claimed that in my second reading speech I refused to refer to the 2 per cent discount recently applied to wages. Of course I referred to that discount. The amendment and the argument of the honourable member are built on a misconception. We are talking about the 2 per cent discount that has already applied. As I said in my second reading speech, on 26 June, in the national wage case decision brought down on that day, a 2.3 per cent increase was granted in relation to the September and December 1985 consumer price index increase of 4.3 per cent. The 2.3 per cent increase applied from the first pay in July 1986. The difference between the 4.3 per cent which would otherwise have applied and the 2.3 per cent that applied was the 2 per cent, which is the rationale for what is taking place now. The amendment is, of course, nonsense. It is built on a misconception. Superannuation fund pensioners received automatically a 9.2 per cent increase based on indexation on 3 July 1986 in respect of the April 1985 and March 1986 increases in the CPI. To introduce equity, the Bill is applying a 2 per cent discount. I draw attention to another part of the Opposition's misconceived amendment, which reads: (a) the Bill imposes on Commonwealth superannuitants, without consultation, a burden greater than that proposed for the community generally. It does not. As I have explained, the community generally has already had the 2 per cent discount to indexation applied to general wages. There is no inequity in what is being proposed. The honourable member for MCPherson ( Mr White) made a comment to which I want to refer. He said that members of the defence forces have been required to pay in 5.5 per cent of their salary over a number of years and that now their benefits are being reduced. He seemed to assume that the 5.5 per cent of their salaries covered the benefits that they received. The contributions based on 5.5 per cent of salaries which were paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1984-85, for instance, totalled about $84.5m. All benefits under both schemes are paid from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, and in 1984-85 they comprised about $732m. What a great difference from the sum of the 5.5 per cent contributions. Members' contributions do not subsidise, so to speak, the annual indexation of pension payments. Members who retire without a pension entitlement, for example, receive a refund of their 5.5 per cent contributions. The cost of indexed pension increases is borne by the government of the day, and this Government has not abrogated its responsibilities under the various Acts that provide for an annual increase in Defence Force retirement pensions, but in the current economic climate the rate of pension increase cannot be sustained. For the sake of equity, too, it has been necessary to apply the 2 per cent discount. Most Australians understand the concept of equity, and that applies to those who have retired. These are people who have given their services in the Defence Force and elsewhere and who are beneficiaries of the fund. They will not be making the sort of fuss that the Opposition is making. As I have said, the amendment is a nonsense. The same can be said of the honourable member for Page ( Mr Ian Robinson), who seemed to see some need to suggest that the Bill is in conflict with the Government's desire to extend superannuation. There is no conflict at all. It is a tragedy that for so many years we have had so few people benefiting from retirement benefit funds. The Government has a keen desire to ensure that superannuation is extended to lower income group people in the community who presently do not have this benefit. Even though the times are difficult ones economically, with a reduction in the prices of our exports being imposed from outside the country-these problems are not in any way due to government policy-we are not putting aside our objectives. We wish to ensure that proper retirement benefits go to those who deserve them. The Bill is not in conflict with the Government's desire to extend superannuation. It is a measure which is bringing equity in benefits in line with the 2 per cent discount in respect of wages that has applied to the rest of the community. I commend the Bill to the House. Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: AUSTRALIAN LAND TRANSPORT
text: Murray) (6.05)-The Bill before us is the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986. Its purpose is to reduce the amount of Federal road finance for 1986-87 by $50m to $1,245m. This will be achieved by reducing the hypothecated excise on petrol and diesel fuel by 0.235c per litre, which in turn will reduce the amount to be retained in the Australian Land Transport Program Trust Fund and thus to be available for expenditure on the nation's roads. The MinEmptyHere this bad news in June, but the road construction industry, State and local governments, automobile associations and others can be forgiven for being confused, because since then there has been a further reduction, in the Budget, of $24m. The result for 1986-87 - and I presume we can accept that there will be no further reductionsis the dismal figure of $1 ,245m allocated for the nation's roads, which is the same level in current or nominal terms for the third year in succession. It brings with it an equally dismal record for this Government, because for only the second time in the 11 years during which the Australian Automobile Association chart has provided figures on this, and for which I will seek incorporation in Hansard later, there has been no increase in nominal or current dollar terms for Federal road expenditure. Both of those years were during the term of this Australian Labor Party Government-that is, last year and this year. To understand fully both what this $74m reduction in Federal road finance means to the level of road construction and maintenance and what it does to the incorrect but nevertheless persistent bombast of the Government in relation to its priorities for road expenditure, I shall quote from the Minister's second reading speech on the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Bill 1985. I want to highlight some of the arrogance-which I think must now be obvious to everyone and which we tried to show last year-of the Government. The Minister said: The Bill now before the House will be the foundation upon which our overall approach to transport will be based. It provides a use related basis for determining Federal expenditure on land transport more the arrangements incorporate an automatic adjustment to match future inflationary movements as measured by the consumer price index. BILL 1986 It guarantees the continuity of the greatest road building program in Australia's history, which has been progressively implemented during our two years of government. Together with the Australian Bicentennial Road Development-ABRD-program, federal expenditure on roads will total $1,245m in 1985-86. Later he stated: The Bill establishes a trust fund, which will operate on a similar basis to the ABRD Trust Fund. It provides that an indexed share of the existing excise charge on motor spirit and diesel fuel will be paid into the AL TP Trust Fund based on collections from I July 1985 until 30 June 1990. He further stated: The future level of expenditure under AL TP will· depend upon the following two factors: - The rate of consumption of motor spirit and diesel which is the best measure of road use-and the rate of movements in the Consumer Price Index to maintain the AL TP excise component in real terms. Specifically in this Bill we have the fulfilment of this Government's long standing policy commitment to the improvement of our nation's road system-a system which under conservative governments was starved of essential investment funds. What an arrogance that is when we see what is actually being spent by this Government on the nation's roads. What is the real position with this Government's level of expenditure? There are two ways of determining whether the Federal Government is giving adequate priority to road expenditure. The first is based on excise, that is, the percentage of fuel excise or, for that matter, total Federal fuel taxes-both the excise and the levy-allocated to roads. I believe that this comparison is unreliable because there are, as we are now finding almost daily, considerable variations depending on the import parity price which, in turn, alters the crude oil levy and the excise relationship. Also, it is does not recognise the legitimate right of a Federal government to tax fuel to an acceptable degree as part of that government's income requirement. However, I agree with those who criticise the excessive level of taxation, which amounts to about 9 per cent of total Commonwealth income, when in this current year only about 16t per cent of that amount will be spent on our roads. Let us compare that figure with the high point of over 21 per cent in 1983-84, the first full year of the initiation of the Australian bicentennial road development program by the honourable member for Gwydir ( Mr Hunt) on behalf of the coalition systems. FurtherGovernment. The Australian Automobile Association uses the second form of comparison, that is, the percentage of total government expenditure allocated to roads. Title: COMMONWEALTH ROAD FUNDING AS A PROPORTION
text: The three important columns in that II-year table indicate, first of all, total funding or total Federal expenditure on roads; secondly, the total Budget outlays or expenditure; and, thirdly,-the right hand column-the percentage of total Federal government expenditure which is actually allocated to roads. However, since then, in government, the Labor Party has been very quick in its Press statements and speeches to claim the credit for the beneficial effects of the ABRD program on our road finances. The Labor Government has not just been content with accepting the credit for the ABRD program which it initially opposed; it indexed that 2c per litre levy and has paid all of that indexed portion into Consolidated Revenue. Over the five-year period of the bicentennial road program, over $500m of what should be money in 'Hansard a table supplied by the Australian Automobile Association. Leave granted. The Government and the Minister love to boast how they have given such a high priority to road finance in their Budgets. To make that point, I refer to the Minister's second reading speech. The Government always cites the figure for 1981-82, the last full year of the coalition Government. The Australian Automobile Association table confirms that low point. Let us look at the situation over five Labor Budgets. For a start the figure given for funding in 1981-82 is always wrong because the figure for the last coalition Budget-1982-83-is far higher. Labor has falsely claimed the credit for the 1982-83 funding level. The first full year of the 2c per litre levy, the high point of Federal road finance, was 1983-84. Once again it flowed automatically from the coalition Government initiative. In 1984-85 there was a funding reduction in real terms of several per cent. In 198586 the $1,245m funding level, the figure for the previous year, was retained. Therefore the reduction in real terms is the full extent of inflation for that year. In 1986-87, the current year, the funding level of $1,245m has been retained, once again bearing the full reduction of inflation for the year. The three Budgets that have on them the imprint of Labor-1984-85, 1985-86 and 1986-87-indicate a fall of about 20 per cent in real terms in finance allocated by this Government for road expenditure and maintenance around Australia. That is the real story of what this Government is doing for road finance in this country. The Minister and the Government have been fond of citing in all their Press releases an 82 per cent funding increase in nominal terms since 1981-82. I know that the Government can still use the 1981-82 figure because the Automobile Association table indicates that 1.67 per cent of total government expenditure in 1986-87, compared with I .66 per cent in 1981-82, will be allocated to roads. However, I caution it against that because the Federal· Budget deficit will certainly blowout far beyond the guesstimate of the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) of a little over $3.5 million. Put another way, expenditure for this financial year will be far greater than $74,764 million, and that is the figure on which the Automobile Association table is based. We have only to remember 1985-86 when final Government expenditure was over $800m more than the original guesstimate. The Government has to increase its expenditure by only $236m to $75 billion to reduce that percentage to the same as it was in 1981-82. To get the figure down to 1.65 per cent, which would be the lowest level of Federal expenditure in the II years covered by the Automobile Association table, total expenditure has to increase by only an additional $690m. I again remind honourable members that the deficit blow-out last year was over $800m. Even looking at those figures is being kind to this Government because the calculations do not include AL TP finance, which can be diverted from road expenditure at the request of the States to interstate mainline rail upgrading, and I would be interested to hear from the Minister what is happening in that respect. There is also the uncertainty of further amendments being introduced in the mini-Budget next year, and for that matter, next year's Budget. There is the uncertainty of what to expect in real money terms for road finance in the years ahead. That does not even include one other aspect of uncertainty: The phoney accounting of a $24m reduction in this year's Budget. That $24m is additional to the $50m which we are specifically referring to and is money that is being collected this year from the motorists. It is collected as excise and paid into the AL TP trust fund. It is not being allocated for the much needed expenditure on our roads; it is being kept in the trust fund to artificially reduce the deficit. I return to the earlier point of fuel taxation versus government revenue versus road finance. The Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into Certain Petroleum Products, which is still in progress, is of considerable interest. The second draft report was released in August. It was released ahead of the Budget. But that second draft report is dramatically different to the first draft report which was released earlier in the year. The second report recognises the deliberate Government policy of breaking the import parity price policy by taxing the difference. In other words, instead of the motorists benefiting from the reduced world price of crude oil the Government pocketed the difference. Mr Beale-Did it give it back when the price went back up?

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: It did not. In fact, it made it worse. The House will recall that in the Budget it increased the levy by a further 3c a litre. It just compounded the problem. The lAC is highlighting, to those who read these reports, that this Government is now using fuel as the most direct source of revenue that any government ever has to overcome its budgetary deficit problems. The lAC concluded that the excise on petrol and diesel is too high, and that it is unfair in its impact. I certainly agree with both those points. One has to consider how country people need to rely on fuel for the greater distances, for freight, et cetera. All road users-indeed anyone who is in an export industry-have the added burden of the relatively high price of fuel for use on farms and in other industries in relation to many of our competitors. The lAC in its draft summary recommended: As discussed in chapter 6, and as suggested by a number of participants at the first draft report hearing, a broadening of the commodity tax base by introduction of a Broad Based Consumption Tax (BBCT) or a Value Added Tax (VAT) would be expected to have a number of benefits. In particular, as discussed in the Draft White Paper on reform of Australia's tax system, such taxes would have the ability to relieve the burden on the income tax system. In addition they would provide scope to reduce petroleum excises. The Draft White Paper proposed a BBCT at a rate of 12t per cent. A further $2 billion would be raised by increasing this rate to 15 per cent. This would be sufficient to allow the excise rate on petrol, diesel and aviation fuel to faH to a level more comparable to other products in the economy. We must seriously consider that lAC recommendation. I would be very surprised if in its final report it moved in any substantial way from its recommendation of the introduction of a broad based consumption tax in which fuel is taxed at the same rate as other products and services and not at the punitive rate which it has become in this country, and that specific road user charges be levied, but that all the income derived from those specific road user charges-there are a number of ways in which such charges could be made-would be allocated for the construction and maintenance of this nation's roads. The total cost of the tax and the specific road user charge would be less than current fuel taxes. In addition to the Labor Government's failure to maintain Federal road finance in real terms and the prospect of a continuing and accelerating decline between now and the next election and the end of the ABRD program in 1988, we pose a serious question: What happens after 1988 when the ABRD program and its 2c a litre levy ends? The ABRD now constitutes over one-third of Federal road finance. It is imperative that Federal road expenditure be maintained either by an extension of the ABRD program or by a combined AL TP and ABRD program which in total will maintain the level of road finance for the nation's roads and, what is more, guarantee that that level be maintained, unlike the very uncertain situation this Government has created. Mr MCGauran-1t is certain in one waythat the road funds will be decreased over the years.

Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: The honourable member for Gippsland makes a very relevant and important point on behalf of the rural electorate, that fuel taxes, in total, must be lowered over a number of years but that expenditure must be maintained. The Opposition's concern over the Government's failure to maintain the nation's roads has caused the Opposition to consider an amendment. Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: Throsby) (8.00)-I am pleased to speak on this important legislation put forward by the Government. It is also interesting to follow Opposition members who have spoken on this debate in this place. I was going to say that it is interesting to analyse their speeches but as frankly there was not a lot in their speeches to analyse I will not say that. Obviously I reject the amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray ( Mr Lloyd). I thought it was a bit of a joke where in the preface to the amendment he condemned the Government for its disgraceful neglect of the nation's roads. If there is any group of people in this chamber who should be condemned for the disgraceful neglect of the nation's roads it is those people who occupy the Opposition benches today. During the seven years they had control of the treasury bench they let the roads of this nation fall into decline. For them to come in here this evening and for the honourable member for Murray to move an amendment condemning this Government for the disgraceful neglect of the nation's roads quite frankly is humbug. It is also time that the Opposition parties really decided what they wanted. It is no good them running around the country calling for . cuts. 'Cuts, cuts, cuts' they are saying. They want cuts in this and cuts in that, but they especially want cuts in government expenditur-. As soon as the Government takes an economic decision, they run around the country criticising the Government and calling out 'spend, spend, spend'. They want more money spent on this or on that. In the mornings they call for economic restraint and cuts and in the afternoons they call for more spending. (Quorum formed) I would like to thank the honourable member increas- for Wakefield ( Mr Andrew) for giving me this extra audience this evening. I would like to ask Opposition members where the funds are going to come from for them to do all they claim .should be done, especially on roads, at the same time as cutting costs. They just cannot. We know it, they know it and the Australian people know it. They are just talking humbug. All honourable members accept that road transport is a fundamental part of the Australian way of life. Well designed and constructed roads make significant contributions to Australia. They reduce costs, save lives, encourage all forms of industry and repay to Australia far more than they cost. However, in the current economic circumstances where Australia is under pressure from external factors, it is essential that each section of the economy and of the community makes a contribution to the overall well-being of the country. No government has a better record in Federal road funding than this Hawke Labor Government. There has been a substantial increase in road funding since this Government came to office. I will tell honourable members just how substantial this increase is. Road funding represents an increase of 82 per cent over the amount provided in 1981-82-the last full year of the previous Government. Even when the increased costs of road construction are taken into account, road funding in 1986-87 is still 24 per cent above that provided by the Fraser Government in 1981-82. Funding for arterial roads, which is primarily a State responsibility, has increased by 91 per cent since 1981-82. That is a 31 per cent increase in real terms. Funding for local roads has increased by 60 per cent since 1981-82, which includes an increase of 2 per cent over 1985-86 and an increase of 10 per cent in real terms. Under this Government, Australia now has a fully sealed highway all around the continent. I am sure that all honourable members, like me, felt a sense of pride at seeing the Minister for EmptyHere the last link in the north of Western Australia was sealed a few weeks back. This had been one of the major national highway objectives-another magnificent objective achieved by this Government. Other objectives being met are upgradings to meet the growing needs for safe and efficient road transport between major centres of population. The Government stands by its fundamental objectives and it is committed to improving one of Australia's greatest national assets, our national highway system. Total expenditure on the national highways has been increased by $262m to $564m since we have been in government. In fact, it is the largest Commonwealth works project ever undertaken in Australia's history. Yet the pathetic leremiahs and whingers opposite continue their ignorant bleating. They have no imagination, no daring and totally lack the initiative necessary to build for the nation what it needs most-a better, more efficient transport system to get our goods to market. In my own electorate of Throsby over the past years a considerable sum of money has been spent on the national highway. Work is well progressed on the much needed Berrima-Mittagong by-pass. This work will cost almost $50m. The work by-passing the historic town of Berrima is almost complete. Work has commenced on the second section from the Wingecarribee River to Welby and work is about to commence on the We1by-Alymerton section, which is estimated to cost over $30m. Despite all the money spent on this section, and bearing in mind that not one penny was spent by the previous Government on this section even though it was represented by a Liberal Party of Australia member, the Liberal-National Party members, including the honourable member for Gilmore ( Mr Sharp), who should know better, and the two local State members-the honourable member for Goulburn and the honourable member for Camdenkeep peddling the story that money has been diverted from this section to the Newcastle area. This, of course, is nothing but fanciful fabrication. As well as the millions to be allocated on this section, almost $11 m has been allocated to the Illawarra-Hume Highway interchange and some $18m has been spent in by-passing Marulan. One of the most heavily trafficked and dangerous sections of the Sydney-Melbourne route will thus be eliminated. I am pleased that local roads have been allocated $258m for 1986-87. This is $5.1m more than they received in 1985-86-an increase of 2 per cent. Federal support for local roads also has to be seen as part of a total package for local government. In addition to the increase in specific purpose road funding, general purpose financial assistance for local government is to be maintained in real terms over the next two years. Councils are free to use these funds for any purpose they think appropriate, including road construction and maintenance. Overall, local government has fared well in the Budget, particularly given the present economic circumstances reflecting high levels of Federal commitment to local government. We recognise the restricted revenue base for local government and the pressures being placed on their road systems. For far too long under conservative governments they have been the poor relation. A major proportion of Federal road funds75 per cent-is spent in non-metropolitan areas, maintaining employment and substantiating economic activity in rural areas. It is estimated, example, that for every $1 m spent on better roads, 60 jobs or thereabouts are created. These jobs are vital, especially in country areas. So much for the humbug and hypocrisy of National Party members, such as the honourable member for Cowper ( Mr Nehl), who last week, in this chamber, called for a zero deficit. Yet he blames the Federal Government for the condition of the Pacific Highway, a State road for which we have no responsibility and for which even less money would be available if his plans for the deficit were to be fulfilled. He should explain that to the people of Wauchope and Kempsey, because I most certainly will be explaining to them when I am up that way that he called for a Budget deficit. Last week he called this Budget a Clayton's Budget. He said that there should be real cuts. If there are to be real cuts, where is the money to come from for road funding? The honourable member for Cowper calls for real cuts in the morning and for more expenditure in the afternoon. This is symptomatic of the Opposition's whole approach. Let there be no confusion. The message is clear: We cannot go on spending what we do not earn. If honourable members opposite vote against this Bill, they vote for a higher deficit. They cannot have their cake and eat it too. Their opposition is a fraud. Our fellow Australians who travel over highways and see the fantastic amount of work being done can see that their taxes are being well spent. Some people might be fortunate enough to be driving along one of the super highways into which we have put so much money and listening to this broadcast on their car radios. Those people should ask themselves whether the roads they are driving along are better now, under the Hawke Labor Government, than they were under the previous Fraser Government. I invite those people to write to me and give me their answers. No matter how the Opposition tries to manipulate and juggle the figures, the bottom line is still the same. We have increased total road funding by 82 per cent since being elected to government. The rest from the Opposition is sour grapes. All the arguments about excise revenue and statistical mumbo-jumbo are a smokescreen and are totally irrelevant. This Bill is no more than a temporary alteration to our committed road funding program; and it is totally responsible, given our economic circumstances. No State in the Commonwealth of Australia has received a reduction in funding-I am pleased to see that the temporary Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) is in the chamber to hear for me wind up-and planning for future construction and maintenance can continue unabated. I admit that the expectations of the States might be dented somewhat, but the States being what they are, they have eyes bigger than their bellies. In any case, I can see no reason why the pain of economic necessity should not be shared by them as well as everyone else. It is a pity that we cannot be a generous as we would like to be, but we must face up to the facts. Honourable members opposite are condemned by their own words. They live in cloudcuckoo-land. In short, people in glass houses should not throw stones. I never cease to be amazed at their short memories-their political amnesia. I know that my colleagues who will follow me in this debate will remind them of their appalling record. I commend the Bill to the House.
