Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: The Minister for Transport condemned the program.

Speaker: Mr EVERINGHAM
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: He did. He has condemned so many things. He is the biggest knocker around. I found the second reading speech of EmptyHere little difficult to stomach-almost as nauseating as all the signs one sees when one drives through Labor electorates, which say: The Federal Government-Building Better Roads'. The Government does not seem to appreciate that it is the Australian taxpayer who is paying for those roads. The Federal Government has not built a road that I know of-it has financed a fewexcept perhaps in the Australian Capital Territory. But misleading advertising is not really a problem to this Administration. While speaking in fine phrases about the benefits of roads to all Australian communities and about bringing all Australians together, to use of the words of the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke), this Minister has supervised outside this House a calculated program of withdrawal from exactly those commitments. In particular, the Minister has seemed intent on putting as much distance as he possibly can between northern and southern Australians. This Bill is about reducing the percentage of duty paid on fuel for the Australian land transport program. Talking about fuels, the jokes are even going around the schools these days. They say that the Treasurer ( Mr Keating)-'the world's greatest Treasurer'-is the only man who can defy Newton's law; the price of petrol keeps going up and never comes down. It is ironic that those who individually contribute the greatest amounts to the levy, the long haul truck and road train drivers who cart Australian goods along Australian roads to and from north Australian communities, are made to suffer most under the policies of this Government. This Bill will swipe from the Australian Land Transport Trust Fund much needed dollars for road improvements levied on users who are certainly trying to bring Australians together and will pay it into the bottomless pit of Consolidated Revenue where it can help defray the costs of midnight VIP flights from Sydney to Canberra. We can expect that the nearest these dollars will come to assisting transport needs is by funding some 'peace' bus, or by helping to move the professionally unemployed from one protest site to another. In the life of the Hawke Government, shipping services to the north have been abandoned after a long history of gross ineptitude on the part of the Australian National Line. We had the promise of a railway to the north of Australia. 'Trust me' said the Prime Minister; 'Territorians, you can trust me'. We still have that television commercial. We play it at every election. 'Only a Labor Government can be trusted to build the railway'. That promise was cynically dumped by this Government and this Minister. The promise of new domestic and international terminals at Darwin Airport has been deferred, which is too polite a euphemism for it. Alice Springs Airport, one of the busiest airports in Australia, has been left in the lurch whilst, in a politically discriminatory way, funds have gone to a much quieter airport than either Alice Springs or Darwin airports-to Townsville Airport. Even the allegedly compensatory road programs have been struck from the list of priorities. Yet the Minister has the gall to talk of bringing Australians closer together. The roads within Kakadu are not all that flash either. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment ( Mr Cohen) said the other day, I think, that we can expect an avalanche of tourists and much greater export income as a result of Crocodile Dundee having been filmed at Kakadu. Let me say that the roads and facilities are pretty poor. There are exactly 32 units of tourist accommodation available in Kakadu National Park, because that is all this Government has permitted to be constructed, despite numerous groups wanting to put tourist facilities into the park. When Northern Territorians talk of railing against this Government, it is more than just a deliberate pun. When this Government is thrown out of office at the next election, it will be a matter of great celebration in my distant and remote electorate, the Northern Territory, which, the Minister may care to recall, is still a special responsibility of the Commonwealth. I had cause to mention the accelerated Stuart Highway program in speaking on the 1985-86 Budget. I said then that the program could more aptly be named the 'dust to dust and ashes to ashes program'. Let us look at the historical facts on Australian land transport, particularly as they affect the road program between northern and southern Australia. In 1982, the Australian bicentennial roads program was introduced, with its special emphasis being on the national highway system, and its timing to take us to the end of 1988. The notional allocation to the Northern Territory under that program was determined at $11.1m. In addition, this year the Territory should have received another $4.4m. This extra money was in direct compensation for the totally unnecessary and deliberately punitive freeze imposed upon the Territory's road program by this Minister in 1983-84-the justification being that everything was on hold while the Darwin-Alice Springs railway was under consideration. 'Under consideration' was a nice euphemism. The railway was about as much 'under consideration' as is a chicken on the chopping block. In 1985-86, instead of the expected $15m for roads, being the total of Australian bicentennial road program sharing and the shortfall from the 1983-84 freeze, the Territory received just $10.6 million. That means that the Territory suffered just short of a one-third cut in road program funding in the 1985-86 year. On top of this, the ASH program was totally abandoned. In 198485 this Government announced a program of upgrading for the Stuart Highway of $27m over three years, with $2.7m to be allocated in the first year. This was not an election promise. We are all quite used to seeing those broken, and we might have adopted a 'believe it when we see it' attitude to that announcement had it been so. This was announced as part of the Budget, and was a consequence of the Federal Government's decision to renege on the railway. But in the 198586 Budget the anticipated funding of $8.6m was dropped completely. This year, of course, it has not re-emerged and, as part of across-the-board cuts, the Territory loses a further $800,000 from expected Commonwealth funding. This Government placed an impost of 3c per litre on fuel in the Budget, and a few days later added another 2c under the parity pricing scheme. That 5c a litre total will hit road construction as hard as anything else, with estimates in the Territory being that the price hike will mean a $750,000 cut in capital works. Across all Australia the cuts to road construction will run into the tens of millions of dollars. The net of fuel price hikes, capital works cuts and the penny-pinching thrust of this Bill means that Australia's road programs have suffered a very severe setback. In the Territory alone, even a modest mathematician such as myself can calculate a loss of funding of more than $30m to road land transport over three years. Demon strably, money is not being spent 'bringing Australians closer together'. This Bill is part of the desperate effort of Administration to find funds to finance its maladministration and high spending years in office, and to try to reduce the appalling deficit that it has run up in that time. For the sake of all Australia, I hope that the Government succeeds in reducing the deficit since it must, most certainly, be undertaken as a matter of great urgency. I ask the Minister to drop the rhetoric about bringing Australians closer together while he is demonstrably doing everything to put distance between them.

Speaker: Mr MILDREN
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: Ballarat) (8.25)-1 take considerable pleasure in speaking on the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986 as I think that, once again, it recognises the value of the Australian Land Transport (Finance Assistance) Act 1985. It is important to compare the record of this Government on roads with that of the previous Government. It should be recognised that in 1981-82 the Liberal-National Party Government's outlay on the roads of this nation, in adjusted termsadjusted to current prices; although it certainly did not sound like that in those days-was $685m. In the following year, 1982-83, which was the last year of the Fraser Government's term of office-it did not complete its full term; thank goodness-the figure, in adjusted terms, was $850.9m. For 1983-84, which was the first year of the Labor Government, the figure was increased to $1,195.2m. The figure for 1986-87and last year also-is $1,245m. That is an increase, since the Government came to office, of 81.8 per cent. I do not think that anyone can deny that. It is nonsense for people to talk about pennypinching. In my State of Victoria there has been an increase of 84.3 per cent since that time. The figure went from $137.8m in 1981-82 which, as I said, was the last full year of the Fraser Government-thank goodness-to $253.9m in 198687. I shall now make a comment about funding in Queensland. I recall travelling to Townsville, which is now gloriously represented by my colresult league the honourable member for Herbert ( Mr Lindsay), who is an extremely diligent worker and spokesman for his people. I remember travelling there in 1981. I was very concerned, as were the people in that area, about the appalling condition of the roads in that State. They recognised fully just how serious the effect of those appalling roads was on the development of north Queensland, in particular the development of tourism for those ordinary Australians who just this want to drive up there. At that time, the Fraser Government's miserable contribution to Queensland-(Quorum formed) I appreciate the fact that so many of my colleagues have come into the House expressly to hear this speech. It is interesting, when I was talking about the appalling state of Queensland roads, that it was a Queenslander who did not want to hear about it and that that person was not set down to speak on the Bill. At that time, as I said, the miserable contribution of the Fraser Government to Queensland for road funding was only $139.4m in current prices. This compares with $257.6m, which has been allocated to Queensland by the present Government in the 1986-87 Budget. Compared with the sum allocated to Queensland in the last year of the Fraser Government, this is an increase of 84.8 per cent. Mr Robert Brown-How much?

Speaker: Mr MILDREN
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: An 84.8 per cent increase the highest percentage increase received by any State from the Federal Government. As my friend the honourable member for Murray ( Mr Lloyd) said, much of that has come from Victoria. We do not mind, I suppose, we altruistic Victorians, supporting mendicant States-not too much, though. It bears stating that the Federal Government recognises just how significant is the development of roads to the future of Queensland. This contrasts with the many years of neglect that were evident under the previous Government. It also indicates just how ineffectual were the National Party members from Queensland. It is to the credit of the Labor Party representatives from Queensland that that State has done so well out of the Commonwealth Budgets. It is marvellous to see my friend the honourable member for Bowman ( Mr Keogh) and also the honourable member for Leichhardt ( Mr Gayler) here this evening. One of the major successes of the Government's road construction program has been to achieve a fully sealed highway all round Australia, as has been mentioned by my good friend the honourable member for Throsby ( Mr Hollis). At this point, it is only fair to give credit previous Government, which initiated the Australian bicentennial road development program, even though it must be said that it was introduced as a pre-election device to shore up its collapsing fortunes. Happily, as history records, its electoral ploys failed. At least the program continued. During 1986-87, it is expected that $564m will be expended on the national highway system. The Government is determined to proceed with this program even though, because of the economic constraints imposed upon it by the downturn in returns on exports,'its objectives will take somewhat longer to achieve. I guess this is disappointing to us all. Certainly my constituents in Ballarat will be looking forward to seeing money becoming available for the bypass road round Ballarat and the improvements to the Western Highway. Mr Snow-We can come and see the Swans now.

Speaker: Mr MILDREN
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: That is right. The Swans in Ballarat is a very good football team. I know, because I happen to be their No. 1 ticket holder. In the fiscal year 1986-87, it is expected that there will be a reduction of $50m to $836m in the Australian land transport programs revenue. This follows the decision to cut the excise rate hypothecated to the AL TP by O.235c per litre from I July 1986. This is a special one-off measure that has been taken because of the impact of the current economic stringencies. Now it will, however, maintain the indexation and interest earning integrity of the AL TP. In 1986-87, the ABRD revenue is estimated to be $423.5m. What has to be stressed, however, is that the adjustment of the AL TP excise rate and cash payment limits do not alter this Government's fundamental commitment to the development of a better roads system for Australia. I have been particularly heartened by the responsible attitude of municipalities in my electorate of Ballarat and by their very mature recognition of the Government's determination to control expenditure, yet maintain as high a rate of expenditure on the nation's roads as possible. Mrs Darling-What do they have to say?

Speaker: Mr MILDREN
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: Those people recognise that they will have to ensure that the programs which they put in place are run as cost efficiently as possible. Money is also available for roads through local government grants, if they wish to use them for this purpose. They recognise that, under the local government grants, all local councils did well this year. They recognise as well as does the Government that, with less to the money to spend, the time frame within which the road building objectives are to be met has to be lengthened. But I stress that we are nonetheless committed to our road program. I am proud to say that this Government has directed most of its expenditure on roads to the improvement of national, rural arterial and rural local roads-Mr O'Neil-So they should.

Speaker: Mr MILDREN
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: True. As the honourable member for Grey said, so they should. It is a pity that people on the other side of the House do not recognise the same thing. This represents 75 per cent of the total funds available for road construction. The sums to be spent on the two major programs are $439.6m on the ABRD and $81O.4m on the ALTP, which is a total of $1,250m. I stress once again that the hypothecation principle of the 1985 legislation is unchanged. The AL TP trust fund will continue to receive a specified proportion of the duty of excise and customs levied on motor spirit and diesel fuel. The indexation. provisions will continue for the rest of the AL T program. Under the hypothecation principle, $81Om will be allocated to the trust fund in 1986-87. Over the life of the program, more than $4 billion will be allocated to it. This the first time in history that we have had a hypothecation excise since this program was introduced, and it has given some assurance to road construction bodies-at both State and local government level-of the funding that will come through. It is important to remember that although the AL TP excise rate has been marginally reduced, it will continue to be indexed in line with movements in the consumer price index, thus maintaining the real value of road funding to the States. I support this Bill before the House, and I suggest that there is absolutely no merit in the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition. Therefore, I commend the Bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: Gilmore) (8.38)-The people who live in the electorate of Gilmore are vitally concerned with the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill because, as with most rural communities, roads are a major means of communication-in fact, the most commonly used means of communicationwithin the area. Over the years, people who live within the electorate of Gilmore have become very used to what can only be described in very kind terms as a substandard system of roads within the boundaries of this electorate. For some time, the electors of Gilmore have been talking to me about the need for an improvement in the quality of their roads. During my time as the member for Gilmore, I have looked around the electorate and have seen a number of roads, which, quite justifiably, live up to the reputation of being substandard. Trunk road 92, which runs from Braidwood through to Nerriga to the south coast near Nowra is a road on which many members of this House have travelled. They would agree with me that it is a very substandard road. In fact, it is probably the worse road in the electorate of Gilmore. Certainly, it is an issue that is' of great importance, and that is why this Bill is important to the electors of Gilmore. The Princes Highway, on the south coast of New South Wales, running through Nowra, is a road that could be at best described as a goat track. The Olympic Way that runs through Cowra and Young is a disgraceful road. The road from Crookwell to Boorowa is a disaster. In fact, if honourable members drove on it at this time of the year they would be lucky to get from one end of it to the other. The road from Young to Boorowa via Murringo is a road that, despite a tremendous amount of lobbying, patience and work, is still not of a standard that most people would call satisfactory. Overall, throughout the electorate of Gilmore, there are a host of roads which are substandard. The Bill that is before the House is of great importance to the people in my electorate. Over the last few years we have been given a great deal of hope that these roads might be improved. In fact, when this Bill was introduced, many people thought that it would be the vehicle by which we would get better roads. Of course, as time has progressed, people have suddenly realised that this Bill will not be the be all and end all of road construction throughout Australia. As the honourable member for Murray ( Mr Lloyd) has pointed out on previous occasions, if one takes into account the cutbacks that this Government has made in road funding over the years, there has been a real cut in road funding of about $150m.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: How much?

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: One hundred and fifty million dollars. To put that figure of $150m into some sort of perspective, if one uses as a rule of thumb that it costs about $Im per kilometre of road construction, it amounts to ISO kilometres of beautiful bituminised four-lane dual carriageway highway that could be constructed throughout the country every year. To put it on a more local basis, it represents 1,500 kilometres of the sorts of local roads that most rural Australians drive on-that is, the $100,000 a kilometre type road. Prior to the Australian land transport program, the Fraser-Anthony Government introduced the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund.' This was seen to be a means by which we would get better roads. We would get roads that would not be built in ordinary circumstances. So people in my electorate have been looking for a means to get better roads. In the centre of the electorate of Gilmore is the city of Goulburn. The Hume Highway runs through the main street of Goulburn. At the last count, about six million cars a year travel down the main street of Goulburn. EmptyHere

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: It also has the giant ram, which is a major tourist attraction. Some 720,000 people have been through it in the last 12 months. It was opened by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism ( Mr John Brown) just one year and three days ago. But the people of Goulburn have six million cars a year driving down their main street, in excess of 600,000 semi-trailers through the year and, I am told, in excess of 200,000 buses. Each of those vehicles belches out carbon monoxide, makes a noise and destroys the quality of life that Goulburn residents could achieve if those vehicles were diverted around Goulburn. Of course, the people of Goulburn have looked for some time now for a bypass to be built around the city. The construction of a Goulburn bypass has been an issue that has become quite relevant in the last few months. There has been a great deal of debate in the local media. I would like tonight to refer to some excerpts from the Goulburn Evening Post, the daily newspaper in Goulburn. On Monday, 14 July this year, there appeared a letter to the editor of the Goulburn Evening Post, written by none EmptyHere Morris). In the letter the Minister refers to the promise concerning the construction of a Goulburn bypass. The letter reads: From the outset, the strategy adopted entailed the provision of only four lanes from Sydney to Albury for the Hume Highway by 1988. It makes no commitment on the timing for the completion of any town bypasses such as Goulburn, and therefore, there is no question the Federal Government's deferral of these bypasses. Later in the letter the Minister refers to some comments I have made in the paper previously. He states: Mr Sharp also needs to be reminded that the completion of the existing four lanes through Goulburn rather than a bypass at an earlier date was the clear choice the Goulburn City Council during the consultation which led up to the formulation of the construction program for the Hume Highway. Four lanes have now been constructed, fully paid for by the Federal Government, conforming with that preference. The Minister was saying that there has never been a commitment to build a Goulburn bypass, that the commitment was only to construct four lanes from Sydney to Melbourne. I refer to a document entitled 'Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program-Annual Report 1984-85'. Page 4 reads: SYDNEY-MELBOURNE NATIONAL HIGHWAY Continue work to provide four-lane travel route. Provide bypasses of major towns including . . . Goulburn . . . I refer also to a document entitled 'Capital Works Program 1984-1985-List of Projects'. It states: Goulburn bypass. Construction of dual carriageways including bridges. Commencement 1984-85. Completion 1987-88. Estimated cost $25.0 million. So there has been a commitment in the past to provide Goulburn with a bypass. We still do not have it. The Minister in his letter also refers to the fact that it was the preferred choice of the Goulburn City Council not to have a bypass, rather to have four lanes down the main street. Let us see what the then Mayor of Goulburn City Council, Alderman Ernie MCDermott, said about that comment by the Minister. I point out that Alderman MCDermott, who has now retired, was Mayor of Goulburn for 17 years. He was the Labor candidate for the State seat for a number of years and is a distinguished and well regarded citizen in the local community. Alderman MCDermott is referred to in the main article of the 14 July issue of the Goulburn Evening Post. The first couple of paragraphs read: EmptyHere has placed the blame for the Goulburn bypass delay on the Goulburn City Council-a claim denied by former mayor Mr Ernie MCDermott. Mr MCDermott, who was mayor for 17 years, said today there was never any agreement to delay the bypass in favour of the four lane roadway through . Goulburn. I think that speaks for itself. One wonders what of has happened to the Goulburn bypass. The Minister for Roads in the State Parliament, the Hon. Laurie Brereton, sheds a little light on this question. To give you a little of the background, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Minister for Transport for some time has said: 'It is not up to me to decide whether the Goulburn bypass is built. We as a of Federal Government provide the States with the funds and it is up to the States to determine when and where they will spend those funds, and whether or not you are going to have a bypass around Goulburn'. I will read from a letter which the Minister for Roads in the State Parliament, the Hon. Laurie Brereton, wrote to the State member for Goulburn, Mr Robert Webster, on 15 September this year. He stated: Funds are unlikely to become available for the construction of the Goulburn bypass until the early I990s. If the Commonwealth Government can provide more funds, then the Department of Main Roads would be in a position to advance anticipated commencement dates for a number of works funded under the national over entire highways construction program. Mr MCGauran-He is too busy with Darling Harbour.

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: He is too busy with Darling Harbour, but he should be spending more time on the Goulburn bypass issue, because it is a very serious local issue. So the Minister for Roads in the State Parliament says: 'If the Federal Government were to give me the appropriate amount, I could build the Goulburn bypass as quickly as possible'. One wonders where the money has gone that the Minister refers to as being necessary in order to get the Goulburn bypass up and running. The Minister for Roads sheds further light on this. I refer to an excerpt from the Goulburn Evening Post of 3 January 1986: The State Roads Minister Mr Brereton last week accused his federal counterpart, Mr Morris, of diverting $181 million intended to improve the Hume Highway to special work on the Sydney-Newcastle F3 Freeway. Strangely enough, that happens to be very close to the Minister's electorate. I think that Mr Brereton, in his honesty, has shed some light on what has happened to the money that would finance the construction of not only the Goulburn bypass, but also a lot of other bypasses and a lot of major highways throughout Australia. I suggest that the people of Goulburn have been sold short on this issue. What they will be looking for in future is a government that is prepared to put its money where its mouth is and not juggle the funds to suit its own parish-pump approach to politics. The people of Goulburn and the electors of Gilmore will be looking for a government and a Minister that are prepared to make the Goulburn by-pass a reality.

Speaker: Mrs DARLING
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: Lilley) (8.50)-The Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill and the essential elements of road funding which it embraces represent a set of issues which are at once related both to the security and vitality of our economy and the health and safety of those Australians who participate in it. The question of road funding which this Bill addresses is linked inseparably to road safety and the causal relationship between the construction of a safe and effective road system and the greater safety of Australian road users, a truism which no observer could fail to recognise. For the same reason, no informed observer could ever fail to recognise the impact of the road funding policies of the present Federal Government in this area. This performance, and the comparatively deficient performance of our opponents, is pertinent to the debate. The Hawke Government has a strong record in road funding, and has had since it came to office. It is a record which in comparison with the previous Government shows not only a broader long-term commitment to the overall road funding needs of the nation but an attempt to redress the past neglect of funding needs of certain States which suffered under the unequal distribution of funding in seven years of the Fraser-Howard Administration. Cold, hard facts support this view. Federal road funding has increased substantially since the Hawke Government came to office. This Government has increased the level of actual road funding by 82 per cent since the last full year of the Fraser Government. The greatest individual increase has been in the ing of arterial roads. Despite being primarily a State responsibility, funding has increased by 31 per cent in real terms since this Government came to office. The allocation of funds for arterial roads for 1986-87 and the actual cash increase in Federal funding has been enormous. It has been 91 per cent or $201.6m. That is since the allocation of $422.3m since 1981-82. Funding of local roads has increased by 10 per cent in real terms since the last full year of the previous Government. In 1986-87, the Government will continue to assist the rural sector with 75 per cent of all road funding going into national, rural arterial and rural local roads, creating employment and sustaining economic activity in rural Australia. If we compare these achievements in just three years of Labor Government with the seven year performance of the previous Liberal-National Party Government, the difference is nothing short of spectacular. Let us consider these figures. In the last full year of the Fraser Government, 1981-82, Federal road funding was 25 per cent below that provided in the last full year of the previous Labor Government, 1974-75, and 30 per cent lower than the peak achieved in 1972-73. These figures are significant because they show the comparatively disastrous performance of our opponents in the area of road funding. This Government has maintained a considerable performance over a three-year period and any rationalisation of road funding in this legislation should be viewed within this context, particularly given prevailing economic circumstances. This Government recognises that unless fundamental economic issues are addressed, the longer term implications for all Australians will be far more serious than the impact of a small adjustment to road funding. But this temporary adjustment should not mask the reality of a sustained and real improvement to road funding in this country, which must be appreciated in the context of the overall three-year performance of this Government, and not just within the constraints of this exceptional Budget year. This effectively invalidates any criticism made by the Opposition in this debate about the level of road funding, the excise rate, the national highway, the AL TP, the ABRD or any other aspects of this legislation. This decision to adjust the AL TP excise rate and cash payment limit does not alter this Government's commitment to developing a better and safer road system for Australia. The variation in this excise is a onefundoff measure that is necessary in the present economic circumstances. The essential elements of the AL TP legislation, hypothecation and indexation will not be compromised and more than $81Om will go into the AL TP trust fund to be used for future road funding. For the first time in Australian history, a Federal government has set up a special trust fund to cover main road programs. This GovernEmptyHere Morris) believe in planning for the future of Australia. While the AL TP excise rate has been marginally reduced, it will continue to be indexed in line with movements in the consumer price index, and the real value of road funding to the States will therefore be maintained. The fuel excise for the ABRD program remains unchanged. This Government has been able formerly to allocate a portion of excise for road funding despite difficult economic circumstances. Federal funding of local roads has increased by 2 per cent in this year's Budget and local government will benefit from not only the specific road funding but from general purpose assistance, which will be maintained in real terms over the next two years. The national highway and bicentennial road programs have been enormous successes in the improvement of our roads. Australia now has a fully sealed highway, which stretches around the entire continent. This is something about which we should be proud. We have only to take to our highway to realise the benefits of this Government's road program. A map put out by the Minister for Transport and the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) indicates the national highway very clearly, including improvement of roads, of course, in Tasmania. As I have said, it is something for us to be proud of as a government. Spending on the national highway will increase by $5m in 1986-87, and while some of the considerable objectives of the program may not be achieved within the original time span, the present Government has greatly improved the highway in all States. This issue of equal distribution of road funding between each State is quite significant in debate. The Cameron Federal Road Funding Inquiry into the distribution of road funding is due to report to the Government by the end of next month and there are many issues in my home State of Queensland which have some relevance to the questions faced by that inquiry. In particular, I have been struck by the massive improvement to Federal road funding which has occurred in Queensland since the election of the Hawke Government and the quaint but predictable misrepresentation of that funding by the Queensland Government. (Quorum formed) Mr Deputy Speaker, it will take more than one quorum to stop me speaking about the quaint but predictable misrepresentation of Federal funding by the Queensland Government. The dramatic increase in Federal road funding in my home State is evidence of the Hawke Government's commitment to rectify the past neglect of the previous Liberal-National Party Government. I am all too familiar with the antics of Queensland Ministers in misrepresenting Federal funds in all areas of government policy, and I would like to offer a few facts in this area, which will give a true indication of the situation. An analysis of the amount spent on Federal road funding shows that Queensland has received an 84 per cent increase since that granted in the last year of the Fraser-Howard Government. This represents a real increase of 26.4 per cent for Queensland since the Hawke Government came to office. This figure is notable not only because it is part of a considerable national improvement in Federal road funding, but also because it shows that Queensland particularly has benefited from the policies of the Hawke Government. It is the largest increase of any State and is more than two per cent higher than the average national increase. In every aspect of funding, Queensland has received a generous proportion of the available Federal funds. Queensland has the second highest increase of any State in national and local road funding and the third highest increase in arterial road funding. Arterial roads are usually the responsibility of State governments, yet the Federal Government has increased its spending in this area by 91 per cent since it came to office. I would like honourable members to keep that in mind. In an article in the Courier-Mail this morning the following was said: Mr Hinze told the Australian Road Federation all the blame for the lack of road funds lay with the Federal Government. He said that the State Government recognised this the worth of the Gateway arterial project and allocated all the funds for the roadworks from the South-East Freeway to the Bruce Highway. That is misrepresentation, as I shall demonstrate. In this morning's Brisbane Sun Mr Hinze said that Queenslanders could expect to pay the price for quality arterial roads in the future. He actually has a plan for the Queensland Government to introduce tolls on major Queensland highways. If the Queensland Government were properly to utilise the funding which this Government, under the Minister for Transport ( Mr Peter Morris) has fed into Queensland for roads, instead of misusing it and misrepresenting the situation to cover up its inadequacies, it would not have to call for tolls on arterial roads.

Speaker: Mr SCOTT
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: We know for whom the bell tolls.

Speaker: Mrs DARLING
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: As the honourable member for Hindmarsh has just pointed out, we now know for whom the bell tolls. In the last financial year the Federal Government spent $117.6m on 67 projects on the national highway in Queensland. If any member of the Queensland Government or its former coalition partner wishes to criticise any aspect of road funding in Queensland, it is quite obvious where the legitimate blame must be placed. It must be placed squarely at the feet of the Queensland Government, because the Federal Government has more than fuifilled its role in providing road funds to the State. In fact, if the Queensland Government were less willing to manipulate politically and to misrepresent Federal funding and more willing to co-operate with the Commonwealth by using funds effectively-(Quorum formed) Mr Deputy Speaker, I have been trying to outline the deception of the Queensland Government in misrepresenting the Federal funding of roads in Queensland, which has received the highest percentage-84 per cent-increase in funding. The Queensland Premier attempted in March this year to claim credit for a $44.6m project on the Bruce Highway, which was entirely funded by the Federal Government. In my electorate I have seen evidence of this lack of acknowledgement of the contribution of the Federal Government. The Gateway Bridge and the Gateway arterial road were opened earlier this year to a great fanfare by the State Government. Part of the Gateway arterial road is situated in my electorate, and part in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Griffith ( Mr Humphreys). It came as something of a shock to me to discover that the State Government had given no recognition whatsoever to the $21 m contributed by the Federal Government for the road and associated works in Lilley. In fact, the Premier went on record in the media as saying: The company has provided the bridge and the State government the approach roadworks'. That statement was a clear deception and was designed to alienate the Federal Government from the public relations exercise which the State Government had undertaken in an election year. The State Government has no right to politically manipulate Federal funds, particularly in an area of such crucial importance to the safety of Queenslanders. The deliberately deceptive tactics of the Queensland Government merely highlight the dire situation of a State government on the verge of collapse. State governments, regardless of their political persuasion, should assist Federal governments as much as possible in improving the welfare of all Australians. It is particularly galling that the Queensland Government misrepresents the funds of a Federal government which has assisted the State to such a great extent. There is no doubt about the direct causal relationship between road construction and maintenance and road safety. The enormous increase in road funding under this Government has been a major influence on the reduction of the road toll in Queensland, as well as in the rest of the nation. The yearly total of fatalities on Australian roads has decreased by 12.6 per cent in recent years. This legislation will also play its part in the continuing struggle for the advancement of road safety, and it is in keeping with the economic safety needs of the Australian people. We are facing a situation in which economic restraint must be addressed for the long term benefit of the nation. This legislation addresses this problem by maintaining the integrity of the progress and funding increases achieved to date under this Government and by providing a solid foundation on which future road funding can be expanded and improved for the benefit of all Australians.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: Franklin) (9.1O)-Many Tasmanians will be listening tonight, and I intend to tell them a little about what is happening to their contribution to road funding throughout Australia and about the price they are paying for petrol. Road safety and the construction and maintenance of our roads should be beyond politics, but one always finds that it cannot be because one dog will try to kill the other dog. I have listened intently to the Minister for EmptyHere years. When the Liberal and National parties were in government he attacked and attacked. He now expects everybody to sit back and allow him to take a media run and all the credit for most of the things that are occurring today. I know that that is the name of the game. One must be able to sell, and I must admit that the Minister for Transport has a good way of selling his product. When the taxpayers of Australia are paying for road construction and maintenance it should, to a degree, be beyond politics but, regrettably, it never is. A dog fight always occurs, with statements that a certain amount of funding should be allocated elsewhere and that another amount of funding should be allocated somewhere else. Somebody mentioned freight compensation; it is not called equalisation any more. The people of Canberra are nice people, but $17m plus is spent on their bus service and on the most beautiful roads and footpaths in the world. I compare Canberra with poor old Tassie which has footpaths that one could hardly describe as being suitable to ride a pushbike. Some of our roads need construction and maintenance work. At the moment the people of Tasmania are paying 64c a litre for petrol. In the 1986-87 Budget brought down on 19 August, excise on petroleum products was increased by 3c per litre, together with other increases in July and August. This brings the excise rate to 23.884c per litre. For every litre of petrol sold, roughly 30c goes to the Federal Government. I would like to think that that money was distributed in a fair and equitable way, that every State and every motorist in Australia was paying a fair price. Regrettably, that is not the case. The Prices Surveillance Authority was set up by the Federal Government to bring down fair wholesale prices. It recommends a maximum wholesale price in every capital city in Australia. When I see the petrol prices in the capital cities I actually feel sick inside, because the people of Tasmania probably have the lowest incomes of any people in any State of Australia. Their roads are not as good as those in most other States. They need their motor vehicles and at this point they are paying 64c a litre for petrol. It is hard to understand why they should have to pay it. Mr Nehl-How much are they paying?

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: They are paying 64c a litre. The other day, when I asked the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) a question I tried to be very fair. During the 1983 election campaign the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) consistently said that the petrol tax was stealth at the petrol pump, that everybody at the petrol pump was paying taxation. The Prime Minister, in his election campaign, said that he would reduce the price of petrol by 3c a litre and that he would freeze the price of overseas crude. However, he and the Treasurer got caught in what is occurring. The poor old consumer, the poor old motorist, is just the milking cow for the Federal Government. He is just one who has to pay for some of these hare-brained schemes, the one who has to pay for the construction of roads, the one who has to be able to make the Budget balance and, regrettably, he wants a fair go. We all supported import parity pricing. That means simply that we wanted to pay the same price for local crude as we do for imported crude. We said that we would do it when Mr Fraser was Prime Minister because we wanted conservation. There was a world shortage of oil, we wanted to look for alternatives and we in Australia wanted to be self-sufficient. But at the moment there is a world glut of oil. The other day the price of a barrel of oil went from $US8 to $USl3. It is the cheapest it has ever been. Yet we are still paying, on average, l3c a litre more for our petrol right through Australia than we were when the Prime Minister came into Government. We are still paying more in excise than ever before. The poor people of Tasmania are still paying 64c a litre and they ask whether it is fair. It is not fair. The other day I read an article in the Melbourne Age which was spot on. I rang a young lady, Jenny Conley from the Melbourne Age, who did a lot of research into this matter. I complimented her on the fact that she was able to pinpoint exactly what is occurring in this country. The oil companies need taking to task for what they are doing. They know dashed well that if we are to have fairness in Australia they have to play the game too, as does the Federal Government. If it is fair for somebody to construct roads in Australia for the benefit of everybody, it has to be fair that every consumer, every motorist, pays a fair price. However, Tasmania is paying through the neck. Some of the truckies who are driving around Tasmania tonight, finding it difficult to survive because of the high costs of fuel, tyres, insurance, buying a truck on hire purchase or leasing it, et cetera, must be saying to themselves: 'How much more of this penalty of a high price for fuel can we bear?'. The farmers of Australia are having the same problem. They are paying through the neck. Fishermen and everybody who is involved with transportation is paying. Everyday in Tasmania we hear such glib, open liners as: The poor housewives are paying through the neck for their food products, et cetera'. Nobody gets to the real root of the trouble. It is the high cost of fuel and the high cost of transportation which are killing Tasmania. My friend and colleague the honourable member for Denison ( Mr Hodgman) and my friend and colleague the honourable member for Bass ( Mr Smith) know that what I am saying is absolutely true. The people of Tasmania have had it up to the neck. The situation has reached a crisis level and is having a dampening effect on the economy of Tasmania. The Premier of Tasmania had to increase the price of petrol by 5c a litre in his Budget because he knows that it is the only simple way of getting revenue when he is short-sheeted. The Minister for Transport may laugh, but the people from Tasmania are not stupid; they realise that the Hawke Government has done nothing for Tasmania. The Hawke Government shortsheeted Tasmania in the Budget and regrettably, to balance the Budget, the Premier had to take a step which he did not want to take; he had to increase the price of petrol by 5c a litre. That has had a dampening effect.

Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: They had a gun at his head.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: The Federal Government had a gun at his head, as the honourable member for .Denison says. We need to get a bit of fairness into the .whole system. If the consumers of Australia are to pay 2c a litre for road maintenance and construction under the bicentennial program, and if we are to have a satisfactory highway around Australia for safety and transportation, the collection of revenue must be fair for everybody. I ask every honourable member in the House to help me in my concerted campaign to get equality and a bit of fairness into the pricing of petrol. I do not want to see the price of petrol in Queensland at 43c a litre when the people of Tasmania are paying 64c; I do not want to see it costing 49c in Melbourne when people in Tasmania are paying 64c; I do not even want to see it costing 52c in Western Australia when the people of Tasmania are paying 64c. Arguments can be put forward about the roster system and about there being too many service stations, but the pure and simple fact is that if the Prices Surveillance Authority-an organisation controlled by the Federal Governmentfixes a maximum wholesale price of petrol in Australia-and oil companies can sell below it to suit their whim and fancy, it is to the detriment of all Australians and we need to do something about it. It is to the detriment of the truck drivers, of the consumers who drive cars and of everybody else if it is not done on a fair and equitable basis. I hope that this debate on the road system will be conducted in the same vein. Let us cut out the stupid politics about this road and that road; if we all get down to sane fairness we will get somewhere. I hope my wife is listening tonight. I lost my pet cockie and I hope they find it in Tasmania.

Speaker: Mr SNOW
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: Eden-Monaro) (9.20)-Three years ago road conditions in south-eastern New South Wales were at an all time low. Today, there is no doubt about it, roads are better. Naturally, in a large country with a small number of taxpayers to cover each kilometre of road, it is difficult to achieve the standards of the more populous countries. Between 1975 and 1983 the expenditure on roads was slashed by 23 per cent. Under the dedicated representation of the EmptyHere can compare that 23 per cent drop in seven years with a 12 per cent increase in real terms in three years since that date. The expenditure on roads was down 23 per cent under the Lynch and Howard Budgets. There has been a 12 per cent increase under the Keating Budgets. Expenditure was down $517m under the Lynch and Howard Budgets. It has increased by $144m under the Keating Budgets under the stewardship of the Minister for Transport. It is not as if this Government has increased petrol taxes to the same extent in real terms. In the seven years fuel prices rose by 300 per cent. Compare that 300 per cent increase in fuel prices in seven years with a mere 25 per cent increase in three years to 1986. Fuel-related taxes rose by 400 per cent under the Fraser-Howard Budgets. Tonight some honourable members have consistently called on the Federal Government to cut government spending, yet every time an issue comes up they call for an increase in spending. So tonight we hear yesterday's courageous economic Rambos, the slashers of public spending, coming here and shrinking back into the wet caves of economic darkness where they feel most comfortable. Yesterday'S dries are today's wets. They are dry before they go into battle and wet when they reach the front. Confronted with a vote winning issue, no matter what the cost, they are there saying that the Government is not spending enough. They cannot tell us, they will not tell us, where they will make the cuts. I will tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, where they will make the cuts-where they made them last time and that is roads. How will they do it? (Quorum formed) The Opposition did not like it when I challenged it to tell us where it would make the cuts. As I said before we know where it will make the cuts and that is where it made the cuts last time-on roads. How will that be done? The last statement that I can find from the Opposition makes it very clear. Under its policy it would hand funding for arterial and local roads to the States. Every local council, every ratepayer must have grave reservations about $260m of their taxes especially earmarked for local roads disappearing from their revenue source like quicksilver. Local government funding would have to come from the States, competing with schools, hospitals and other State programs. But it will not happen because ratepayers will not vote for a Federal party which refuses to earmark funds for local roads. Arterial road funding would also be handed to the States under Liberal-National Party policy. Again, people will reject that policy. Today the Federal Government is specifically earmarking $420m for arterial roads such as the Princes Highway, the coast road from Queanbeyan to Bateman's Bay, and other important arterial roads throughout Australia. Imagine what would happen if responsibility for $90m of arterial road funding to Queensland was handed over in its entirety to the present Queensland Government. The honourable member for Lilley ( Mrs Darling) tonight quoted Minister Hinze in Queensland who is threatening a toll on Queensland road users. A newspaper headline reads: 'Hinze plans toll on roads'. What would he do in the unlikely event of a Federal coalition government asking his Government to find $90m for arterial road funding. Of course, that would require an impossible coincidence; first, the tion of a Federal Liberal-National Party government, and secondly, the re-election of a National Party government in Queensland. It is a government with the highest total per capita fees in the nation. It has been my privilege in recent years to represent the Hawke Government at the opening of a number of important bridges and roads in the Eden-Monaro electorate. A couple of months ago I opened the Sutton interchange on the Federal Highway. It was an excellent opening. A couple of months before that I opened the Burbong bridge on the coast road. More recently, I opened the two bridges at Numerella on the Monaro Highway. I attended with the State Minister for Roads the opening of the Saucy Creek bridge out of Bombala. Next Monday I will be opening a bridge near Bega. Spending on roads returns a dividend to the community. Better roads mean less fuel costs, less accidents, less wear and tear, and cheaper transport. I welcome the assurance of the Minister for Transport that he will quickly deal with any request from the New South Wales Government for funds for the Princes Highway and the coast road on the basis of a high priority by that State. There is also important work to be done on trunk roads 91 and 92 in my electorate. As I said, we are a small nation in population but a big nation in geographical area. We have a lot of responsibility. I congratulate the Government, particularly the Minister, on the way it has handled those responsibilities.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: OF TOTAL COMMONWEALTH BUDGET
text: O'Connor) (9.28)-We all know that this Government is capable of just about doing anything with figures. I have a simple economic theory that says two plus two equals four. Under this Government it can be any figure. The honourable member for EdenMortaro ( Mr Snow) was just saying how the Government has managed to increase road funding. I think he used a figure of $140m. That is just not enough. The funding for the Australian bicentennial road development fund that was instituted by the previous Government would have to be close to $500m this year. I say that because I note that the Minister mentioned a figure of $440m last year. Even he, of course, fiddles with figures because in his previous second reading speech in this place on this subject he said: As I have noted earlier, together with the $440m to be provided under the ABRD program, the Federal Government's road building program in 1985-86 will total $1,245m an increase of 82 per cent on 1981-82. elecThe first point I make about 1981-82 is that it had only half the ABRD collections then because it was introduced at Ic per litre and later expanded to 2c per litre, and it was an initiative of the previous Government. What is this Government doing in this Budget-the greatest sleight of hand trick since the Treasurer worked out how to get $17,000 of the taxpayers' money on his house. The sleight of hand trick is that the Government is leaving money in the bank. The Government is putting the tax burden on Australians but it is then leaving it in the bank in the Australian bicentennial trust fund so that it can say to Australians that there is some fiscal restraint. I am all for fiscal restraint. I will not be classified in any category, but I am all for fiscal restraint. But let me tell honourable members that when I set out to save money, I save it in the places where it is best saved. I certainly will not cut down spending on roads and those things which the Minister for Transport ( Mr Peter Morris) tells us are of great importance to our nation. When the Minister was booming up this policy in his previous second reading speech, which is like the accord-we are getting into the Bicentennial and the Australian land transport program or whatever we call this particular thing-we are getting into mark 2. The next one will be mark 3 and everyone will spend a little less money. We will just be doing it a different way. This is what he said: I cannot emphasise too strongly the importance that efficient transport systems have to the economic well-being of all Australians. About $1 in every seven spent in this country is on transport. Transport impacts on every facet of our economic and social activity. If he believes that, what is he doing letting road funding be cut? The Government did not cut expenditure this year; it is spending more mopey overall. All this carping we have had here about our overseas problems has ignored the fact that this Budget is the biggest taxing Budget an,d the biggest spending Budget in the history of Australia. It just so happens that this Minister was unable to protect his portfolio and so he got the cuts. But that is not so for the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment ( Mr Cohen). He did not have any cuts. He had an increase in real terms, which was reported in the Australian.

text: Herbert) (9.42)-The Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986 amends the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 by varying the rate of duty calculated in accordance with section 16 of the principal Act from 3.845c per litre to 3.61c per litre, to apply from 1 July 1986. The Australian land transport program, initiated by the Hawke Government, represents the commencement of a truly national transport strategy for Australia. It is a comprehensive strategy. It addresses the problems of providing adequate funding in a cohesive way for roads, railways, transport research and road safety. It will ensure that Australians receive an efficient transport system and that their economic well-being will never be impeded by an inadequate transport system. Prior to the election of the Hawke Government in 1983, and with the notable exception of the Whit lam Government, the history of road funding by the Commonwealth was a sorry record of deliberate neglect. In the early 1920s the Hughes Government provided assistance to the States for roads, primarily as a means to alleviate unemployment, especially among ex-servicemen. Previously, some Commonwealth funds had been made available through the Department of Repatriation for making or repairing development roads. The Main Roads Development Act 1923 represented the first occasion on which the Commonwealth used its powers under section 96 of the Constitution to 'grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as the Parliament sees fit'. That is, it was the first form of specific purpose grant. A grant of $1 m was provided to the States in 1923-24 for expenditure on the construction of main roads, main trunk roads between important towns where no railways were provided and arterial roads through country areas unable to finance the heavy costs of road construction. The basic argument used in support of Federal Government road funding-to speed up the construction of main roads-is still used in support of Federal Government road grants today. North Queenslanders bitterly remember that it was not until 1962, some 13 years after the Menzies Government took power, that the Bruce Highway from Brisbane to Cairns was completely sealed. In 1974 the Whitlam Labor Government introduced the National Roads Act and the Road Grants Act and thereby assumed full funding responsibility for roads which had been identified as being of special national significance, such as the national highways. This ambitious program to rebuild the land transport system of Australia was dealt a savage blow by the Fraser Government. For example, real road grants by the Federal Government to the States were slashed by 29.5 per cent during the seven years of the Fraser Government. Queensland suffered a major cut in Federal funding for roads. Almost all State governments and councils in Australia were furious at Federal government cutbacks in road funding. Honourable members will vividly remember that during the years of the Fraser Government, Australian roads were cracking and crumbling under the strain of declining Federal government real funding for our national road network. There is no doubt that the Fraser Government's culpable failure to allocate a fair share of road users' taxation to the upgrading of Australia's road system was a direct cause of the increased tragic toll on the roads. It was an act of brutal cynicism and displayed a callous disregard for human life. The national highway was falling into decay. The then chief executive of the National Roads and Motorists Association, Mr George James, was reported in the Australian of 19 March 1982, as saying that the Fraser Government bore a 'great responsibility for the failure to reduce the road toll'. He continued: If New South Wales wants to achieve a major reduction in the road toll it will have to receive much treatment from the Federal Government. In New South Wales we have how reached crisis point. We are now seeing the wastage of assets which will take generations to repair. He blamed the cutbacks on the then Federal Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Gwydir ( Mr Hunt). On 17 March 1982 a report by the Bureau of Transport Economics on road construction price indices was tabled in this Parliament. The report confirmed that Fraser Government road funds, expressed in real terms, had been sharply reduced. It showed that road construction costs rose by 15.9 per cent in 197980 and by 15.3 per cent in 1980-81. These rises compared with increases in Fraser Government road funds of 7.5 per cent in 1979-80 and 11 per cent 1980-81. This sharp reduction in Fraser Government-funded road works was made when road users were being clobbered with a heavy fuel tax, levy increases and record personal taxation. The Liberal member for Franklin ( Mr Good luck) was a member of the Fraser Government that trebled the price of petrol, quadrupled the fuel-related tax take and slashed more than half a billion dollars from road expenditure. In 1981 more than 3,500 Australians were killed and about 90,000 were maimed or injured on Australia's roads. The appalling death and injury toll on Australia's roads, which cost $4 billion in the last year of the Fraser Government in monetary terms alone, was fostered by the Fraser Government's low priority on roads. There was no fairness in the Fraser Government's policies. While motorists paid the burden of tax evasion by shrewd operators, the Liberal National Party Government squandered millions of dollars on lavish living for itself-international safaris, purchases of Boeing 707 flying hotels for overseas junkets, personal chefs and butlers, and propaganda to prop up an incompetent and dying government. When the Hawke Government came to office, it was faced with a massive Budget deficit. During the 1983 election campaign it was suggested by the Fraser Government that the prospective 1983 Budget deficit would be of the order of $6 billion. After the election it was revealed that the prospective deficit was $9.6 billion. Notwithstanding these considerations, the Hawke Government recognised that a high priority had to be given to investment in roads as a basis for aiding economic development and creating jobs and to redress the decline in the road system which had occurred due to the previous years of Fraser Government neglect. 0n 13 November 1984 the Prime Minister of better Australia ( Mr Hawke) pledged to the Australian people that his Government would continue the greatest road building and maintenance program in Australia's history, that within the next three years the national highway system would be brought to an all-weather, dust-free and floodfree standard, and that the Bruce Highway would be transformed to give the growing cities and towns of north Queensland the genuine highway standard link they need and deserve. (Quorum formed) As I said, on 13 November 1984 the Prime Minister pledged that his Government, an authentic Australian government, would initiate the most comprehensive overhaul ever undertaken of Australia's national transport system. In 1985 the Hawke Government passed legislation establishing the Australian land transport program. For the first time, Australia had a truly national transport strategy. The Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 established a trust fund into which would be paid, as from 1 July 1985, an amount equivalent to 3.66c per litre of net revenue collected from Customs and excise duties on motor spirit and diesel fuel. That rate was to be subject to an adjustment twice yearly in line with movements in the consumer price index. The rate has been increased, from 1 August 1986, to 3.755c per litre. This provision is consistent with Australian Labor Party policy of returning a fairer share of fuel related revenue to road works funding. Revenue from this duty during the year 198687 is estimated at $8 10m. Funds payable from the Australian Land Transport Program Trust Fund will be allocated on a percentage basis to national roads, urban arterial roads, rural arterial roads, local roads, land transport research and road safety. The Australian land transport program replaced the Roads Grants Act scheme which expired on 30 June 1985. The Australian bicentennial road development program is continuing separately. Federal Government funding under the Hawke Government's Australian land transport program and the Australian bicentennial road development program will provide a record $1,250m for road construction, maintenance and research in 1986-87. By way of contrast, during the last full year of the Fraser Governmentthat is, 1981-82-a miserable sum of $685m was allocated for all road construction and maintenance. In other words, the allocation of Federal funds under these Hawke Government programs is 82 per cent more in money terms and 25 per cent more in real terms than that provided by the Fraser Government in 1981-82. Total spending on the 16,OOO-kilometre national highway will increase by $569m in this financial year compared with $559m last financial year. The urgent need for adequate roads and the ever-increasing pressure on Australia's road system, especially the national highways, demand that road funding be placed on a predictable and assured basis. Now, for the first time ever, road funding under the Hawke Government is on a predictable and assured basis. Hawke Government road legislation gives encouragement for State and local road authorities, the construction industry and equipment suppliers to plan over a longer term, thanks to the certainty of funding. In contrast, the policy of the Liberal and National parties is the abolition of specific local road funding for the States and local government authorities. The Australian land transport program provides the most comprehensive approach ever in funding for roads. This program will sustain the record level of Federal funding for roads which has occurred since the Hawke Government came to office. The Hawke Government is determined to achieve its commitment to upgrade the national highway system by 1988. The accomplishment of this great national undertaking will earn for the Hawke Government the enduring gratitude of every Australian. It is the fulfilment of a pledge made to the Australian people in the 1984 election policy speech by the greatest Prime Minister in Australia's history, Bob Hawke.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Dundas) (10.13)-ln the adjournment debate tonight I want to talk briefly about the concept of multiculturalism and the importance to Australia of the extent to which this Government has let down the migrant community by largely terminating the English as a second language program. I think it is important that people understand what multiculturalism means, because it is the concept by which we talk of the important respect that people have for the values, culture and background of people from different countries who have settled in Australia. It is not separatism, as some people often seek to advance. Certainly, one of the most important programs designed to ensure that multiculturalism is not separatism is that in which migrants are encouraged and aided to be able to speak English and to communicate within our community. This is a very strong view held by migrants whom I have met over the time that I have been in public life. It is evidenced by the desire of migrants, when they settle in Australia, to learn English and, particularly, the aspirations that they have for their children and their families in the Australian community. It was therefore with great alarm that I learnt in the Budget that the Government had decided to reduce by almost half the amount of funding available for the teaching of English as a second language-the ESL program. It has been most distressing to migrants, their families and the teachers who are involved in assisting such young people to overcome the very significant disadvantage that they suffer. Budgets are always a difficult question. It has always seemed to me that it is a matter of priorities. If priorities had to be determined in the cutting back of government expenditure in the education area, there are much more fundamental areas, I think, in which changes could have been made than the area of these ESL programs. I would have seen it as being most important to maintain those programs. In order that one can see this in perspective, I think one should look at one of the Government's own reports on this matter. I quote from the report of the Karmel Quality of Education Review Committee, in relation to the funding of programs in this area: The immigration program brings to Australia each year a sizable number of students who have minimal or no proficiency in English on their arrival. Their need for intensive instruction in the English language is immediate and obvious. Without access to English they are deprived of access to education and to an alien culture. Within the group there are those whose pressing needs extend beyond English language instruction because they are illiterate in their mother tongue. These tend to be young people with refugee status who have received no schooling in their homeland or whose schooling has been seriously interrupted. The Commonwealth, which is involved in bringing migrants to Australia, in inviting them to settle here, has a special responsibility in this area. The maintenance of these programs is of the utmost importance. I do not think the States, which will have the responsibility of ensuring that these programs are maintained, will see that they have the same responsibility in this area. I suspect that these programs will be sacrificed when the States have to examine their own priorities. In particular, the smaller States may not have had the same experience in these areas. Some schools which offer these programs, such as those in my own electorate, have small classes. Sometimes only 30 or 40 children in a school require special assistance through the English as a second language tuition program. These schools will be particularly disadvantaged and are more likely to see those programs terminated as a result of the need to save funds in this area. It has been suggested that in New South Wales up to 30,000 children may be disadvantaged through these programs being discontinued and through the lack of access to English as a second language program. It has also been noted that it may lead to a significant number of migrant students having their schooling terminated early if programs of this sort are not available. These cuts that have been made by the Federal Government run counter to advice that the Commonwealth has received through the Schools Commission to increase the amount of funding available in this area and not make a reduction. I must say that I share the view of migrants and teaching authorities who have commented on these decisions that the Government in its more recent steps has been in the business of obfuscation rather than clarification of the situation. One can only describe the Government's more recent announcement as an insulting confidence trick in relation to the migrants and young people who are in need of this very special service.

Speaker: Mr LANGMORE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Fraser) (1O.18)-This House is too commonly a forum for destructive conflict. Disputes are sometimes created artificially, as they were by the Opposition this noon, to attempt to achieve a perceived tactical advantage. But the result commonly is simply to undermine the authority of parliament in the community. There is also, however, much constructive discussion. Tonight I want to mention some centrally important good news for the people of the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister for Territories ( Mr Scholes) today released the economic report for the Territory for the June quarter. That report shows that there has been particularly rapid growth of employment in Canberra during the last year. In 198586 the number of people in employment in the Territory increased by 8 per cent, by 9,600 people. This is a remarkable increase. To provide a point of contrast I mention that the Australian population is growing by about 1.6 per cent a year. Total employment in the whole of Australia increased last year by 5.3 per cent, which was itself a remarkable achievement. National employment growth at this pace is the result of successful economic policies. Moderately expansionary fiscal and monetary policies, combined with falling labour costs, in substantial economic and employment growth. The particularly rapid growth of employment in Canberra was influenced by both this national trend and the stimulus given to the local economy by public expenditure. There was substantial growth of employment in public administration and defence. A significant contribution came from the opening of the new Australian Defence Force Academy. Employment remains strong in house building and construction. In the year to March the value of building and construction work totalled $715m, of which about 30 per cent was for private and public housing, 15 per cent was for offices and 16 per cent was for the new Parliament House. That high level of building and construction activity stimulated growth and employmt!nt in other industries such as the wholesale and retail trade, manufacturing and community services. The strong employment growth has reduced unemployment. In the June quarter it was down to 4.6 per cent, and only half of those unemployed were look,ing for full time work. Youth unemployment, too, is low. Most 15 to 19-year olds are attending school, college or university. Of those who are in the work force, the present unemployment rate is 19 per cent, which is about the same as the national average. This is high and of great concern, and continuing to reduce that rate must have a high priority. However, two-thirds of the youth unemployed are looking for part time work. It is clear that many afterif not most of these are students wanting to supplement their income. Total unemployment is low and it is falling despite the fact that the population of the Australian Capital Territory grew last year by 4.5 per cent. The proportion of the adult population now in the work forcewhat is called the participation rate-is 73 per cent, compared with the national rate of 62 per cent. This makes the achievement even more remarkable. I have concentrated on employment and unemployment because these are central concerns in Australia. The issue to which most Australians would like the Government to give high priority is employment. There has been rapid growth in employment throughout Australia for the past three years and unemployme\lt has fallen significantly, but it remains a serious problem. There are still over 600,000 people who want to work and are actively looking for work but who are unable to find a job. For these people, unemployment involves poverty and often loss of personal dignity. No community can be satisfied with this situation. The Government and the resulted whole community must make employment growth one of its top priorities. This is a difficult task but the last three years have shown that progress is possible. The principal requirement is a strong commitment to the goal of reducing unemployment.
