This was a response to the well-known criticisms of the way the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal was carrying out its responsibilities. These weaknesses had been long standing and were acknowledged in the final reports of the old Australian Broadcasting Control Board. On 19 April 1984, the ABT publicly announced that it had commissioned Professor Neil Runcie to conduct a review. The Press release said: The Tribunal considers itself extremely fortunate in securing Professor Runcie's services, especially considering his extensive knowledge and experience in economic and statistical matters and close personal interest in the electronic media. Why, then, were Professor Runcie's recommendations hidden from public scrutiny? In view of the public announcement of the review, the public would have expected a public report of the outcome of the review. The report was apparently due by 30 June 1984, but there was not mention of it in the 1984 or 1985 annual reports of the ABT. With some difficulty I have obtained a copy of the summary volume. The ABT was not forthcoming when I sought this report and it was necessary for me, as a member of parliament, to use the Freedom of Information Act to prise it out of the ABT. In contrast with the public fanfare given to the commissioning of the review, the receipt of the report and its contents have been kept very quiet. No wonder-because to make the report public would expose the ABT's serious internal weaknesses. The preamble of the Runcie report points out that: to undertake economic analysis in the Australian broadcasting system three elements the ABT requires: (i) an organised database; (ii) a body of economic studies of the broadcasting industries, and; (iii) qualified persons to apply economic perceptions and tools to the many broadcasting problems requiring government decisions. The ABT is lacking in all of these areas. Professor Runcie also said that the information requirements of the ABT are wider than economic data, as the electronic media affect every aspect of our educational, social entertainment and cultural activities. In a biting comment at the end of the report, Professor Runcie says: Indeed, the ABT has been likened to 'Dad's Army' fighting imaginary battles with out-of-date equipment and getting in the way of the main broadcasting battalions. There is substance to these criticisms and the ABT must guard against the en tropic effect of its 'closed system', created by its excessively legalistic nature. He goes on to say: Throughout this report I have advocated a multidisciplinary research programme to open up, as it were, the 'closed system', thereby helping the ABT to serve better its functions and the Australian community. The Runcie report documents many of the weaknesses in the present system and lists over 120 recommendations. It criticises the Coffs Harbour inquiry which was confused, costly and lengthy, confirming the need for more systematic information gathering from established stations as well as applicants for licences. The Broadcasting and Television Act places a clear responsibility on the ABT to act as an information collecting body for the community, not just itself. The Runcie report expresses doubt about the ABT's fulfilment of this role. It strongly criticises the chaotic state of reporting by public broadcasters due to the confusing and inadequately designed forms used by the ABT. I ask the Minister for Communications ( Mr Duffy) four questions: Has he read this report? Why has the ABT been so secretive about it? Has it implemented the recommendations of the report? If not, why not?

Speaker: Ms MCHUGH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Phillip) (10.36)-I rise to speak, as so many of us have so often in the past, on behalf of the people of Chile, who have suffered now for 13 years under the repressive regime of the military dictatorship of General Pinochet. It is now 13 years since that dictatorship overtook the democratic processes in Chile. The torture, the killings, the imprisonments and the disappearances in Chile over those years have been well documented by groups such as Amnesty International. On Sunday 7 September 1986, after the attempt on the life of General Pinochet, the military regime reimposed the state of siege. The result of that has been a very much increased imposition of the repressive mechanisms of that regime. This has worsened the effect felt by the people of Chile. To make the Australian public and the Australian Government more aware of what is happening in Chile, 11 young Chilean refugees in Australia began a hunger strike on 10 September, in Sydney, Melbourne and Perth. Since 4 p.m. on 10 September they have been refusing food. Six of those young Chileans are still fasting. Representatives of the Chilean youth came to Canberra today to make us aware of why their colleagues are undertaking that fearful way of showing the Australian public just how bad the repressive regime in Chile is. I read to the House the following statement that those young people put out: Without any doubt, the reintroduction of the state of siege is just another measure used by the Chilean regime to increase its repression against those who oppose the dictatorship, and a way of openly arresting leaders of political and social organisations. In less than 24 hours, after the reinstatement of the state of siege, hundreds of people were arrested,this is just in the last few weekssome of whose whereabouts are not known, there have been massive and selective house searches, specially in shanty towns, all forms of meeting are banned. There is total censorship of the press, personal mail is intercepted and interfered with and any person who is arrested risks . . . exile and disappearance. Amongst those who have been killed is Jose Carrasco, a member of the National Body of the Journalists Union. He was found dead on Monday the 8th in a street in Santiago. He had been shot in the head 10 times. Amongst those who have disappeared are the President of the Popular Democratic Movement, a clergyman and member of the executive body of the Popular Democratic Movement, members of the Democratic Alliance and a number of leaders of the teachers union. Ei'ght priests have been arrested in the last few weeks and most of those arrested were taken away in front of witnesses as were four students who were abducted by the CNI, the secret police, from a Dutch diplomatic car. Recently, with members of Amnesty International, I visited the Chilean Ambassador in Canberra to protest against the regime in Chile. We did not have to suffer the sort of thing that goes on in Chile when we made diplomatic representations. The Chilean youth resident in Australia have asked several questions of the Australian Government and the Australian people. They have asked the Australian Government, through a public statement, to condemn and denounce the recent escalation of repression imposed since the reinstatement of the state of seige. They protest and question the presence of the Chilean representatives in Australia who recently have made statements to the effect that everything in their country is all right and that the situation is the fault of those who are arrested. Is it the fault of the eight priests who were arrested recently? They call on the Government to interrupt the subsidies given to the private sector if it maintains economic ties with Chile. They call on the World Council of Churches to make a public statement regarding the latest wave of repression and violation of human rights inflicted upon the Chilean people and the Chilean church. They call upon the citizens of Australia to denounce the repression and come out in solidarity with the Chilean cause through their respective organisations, and I join them.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Wakefield) (10.41)-1I have come i!lto the chamber to participate in this adjournment debate following an outburst just a few minutes ago from the honourable member for MCMillan ( Mr Cunningham). As the Acting Government Whip he challenged the role of the Opposition Whip and expressed his concern and indeed criticised the Opposition's tactic in having alerted you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the absence in the House of sufficient members to form a quorum. I rise tonight to express my indignation that members of the Government should see a quorum as some form of punishment. Those who serve in this chamber ought to recognise that the requirement that one-third of the members of the Parliament be present is not an unreasonable demand to make. There are those who have said-as did the honourable member for McMillan-that the calling of quorums by the Opposition has been done in an irresponsible and bloody-minded fashion. For as long as I have been the Deputy Opposition Whip-indeed as long as I have been a member of the Opposition-I have not known quorums to be called in either a bloody-minded or irresponsible fashion. Every member of the Government ought to know that there has never been a quorum called by this Opposition which was not first precipitated by a member of the Government abusing Question Time. There are those who will raise their voices in indignation but five minutes is not an unreasonable period to be set aside to answer a question. It is as much time as the House makes available for a speaker to participate in an adjournment debate. At no time. I stress thishas a quorum been called in this House without it first being precipitated by a Minister taking more than five minutes to answer a question. I take up the point made by the honourable member opposite. The calling of a quorum is not intended as a punishment but Government members seem to see it as such and so the honourable member for MCMillan expressed indignation about it. If honourable members want an illustration of the even-handed approach by the Opposition Whip to this whole exercise I will tell them that yesterday, in what was an impeccable performance by Government Ministers, no quorums were tripped. Inevitably, in the heat of the chamber, there are those who, from time to time, call a quorum without the Whip being aware of its happening. I have no doubt it has happened no matter who has occupied the Opposition benches. Nonetheless, there is such a reservoir of uncalled quorums in the Opposition Whip's office that if it went on forever it would not matter. The calling of quorums is decided each day and no quorums are ever called prior to Question Time, nor are any called unless Ministers take more than five minutes to answer a question. If the honourable member for MCMillan felt that today's exercise was a little hard for the soft-centred Government members to take, let me remind him that after six minutes he tripped two quorums, after seven minutes three and a good deal more could have been called. I restate the case. It is an indictment on the Government to see the calling of quorums as some sort of imposition on it. It seems that this Government has been anxious to avoid the scrutiny of the House. I am pleased that the Special Minister of State ( Mr Young) is in the House this evening because he has accused the Opposition in the past of declaring Bills urgent Bills more frequently than he has. Such an accusation is nonsense, and any survey of the figures will indicate that the Hawke Government has declared Bills urgent far more often than did the Fraser or Whitlam governments. The Whitlam Government declared urgent an average of 20 Bills per year, the Fraser Government two and the Hawke Government l6-a case, I fear, of this House and its Standing Orders once again having been conveniently abused by the people who occupy the government seats.

This is an Opposition that cannot get its message through at Question Time. I have copies here of the answers given to questions asked by the Opposition and asked by the Government that required lengthy answers. The Opposition set the criteria at Question Time today. Would the House like me to go through them again? I certainly could not do it in five minutes. In an answer by the Leader of the House time was put to good use. The Opposition has not heard the last of that issue if it wants to use these tactics in the future.

Speaker: Mr COWAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Lyne) (1O.51)-The matter I wish to raise tonight concerns the harnessing of Australia's water resources. It has concerned me for a number of years. There has not been sufficient finance to further water conservation. At the present, I do not think we should accept the fact that our markets for primary industry are not good throughout the world as a reason why we should not use more funds generally for these most important projects. I realise that although it is the responsibility of the States to undertake these projects, over the years it has been the responsibility of the Commonwealth to undertake such projects as the Snowy Mountains scheme, and the Burdekin Dam in Queensland. Nevertheless, it is our responsibility as the collector of funds in Australia to see that we have more money available for the development of this great continent. No matter what state our markets are in, no matter what state the economy is in, we will still be dependent upon the products from the farm to earn the wealth for this great nation of ours. Therefore, it important that we should not be left behind in the development of water conservation in our streams and our dam sites throughout Australia. Not only are these resources used for irrigation on farms but they are used also in many cases for domestic purposes. There is also a challenge today for the farmer to grow alternative crops, most of which are smaller crops such as oilseeds, maize, lucerne or other crops for which there may be markets within Australia and overseas. To be able to produce these crops at a reasonable cost it is essential that farmers have water for irrigation. If one goes to America, Europe, or most primary industry countries throughout the world one finds that those countries have harnessed all the resources that they possibly can. In the western water district of California, in Sierra Nevada, there are about 250 dams which have been filled by melting snow. We do not have that quantity of snow here; we are not as lucky as America or other countries. We have done what we can with the snow we have in developing the Snowy Mountains scheme. But we have other natural areas which we can harness. We have rivers running into the sea and we can divert water from one area to another. These things can be done economically. All the States have done a magnificent job in many respects. The State Ministers for water conservation have been restricted because they have not had the funds available. There is a tendency today-particularly for the Commonwealth and for most of the States-to disregard our gIeat challenge to develop water resources. It is a challenge that we, as responsible people, cannot afford to let go. If we are to sustain our primary industries-42 per cent of our exports depend on what is termed 'off the farm'-and if we are to meet the challenge of the economy of this nation over the years to come, we must meet that responsibility and divert more of these important funds into the great natural resources that we have in Australia. Not only are dams such as the Keepit Dam used for irrigation and domestic supply but they are used also for tourism.

Speaker: Ms MAYER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Chisholm) (10.56)-I am appalled at the outrageous hypocrisy of the Opposition members in this House. Time after time honourable members on that side of the House have uttered pious platitudes about the value of family life, yet when a Minister arranges that his family should not be left alone for many days at a time, the Opposition attacks him. Does the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) have to neglect his family, have his young children grow up without a father, in order to do his job? Are Opposition members guilty because they choose politics before their children, or are they simply applying their usual double standard? This afternoon the Treasurer reminded the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) of a simple fact. If the Treasurer had sent his family back to Sydney, the Opposition would not have even raised this issue. If the Treasurer's wife and young children lived in Sydney while he worked his usual six to seven day week in Canberra it would not have attacked him at all. Who raised this issue? It was the honourable member for the Northern Territory ( Mr Everingham), who moved his family to Brisbane so that he could be with them more often. He said, and I quote from the Sunday Territorian of 22 December 1985: I am trying to fix up my personal life so that the people who depend on me are in the best personal situation . . . If I were a solicitor it would be different, but I am a Federal member who's away a lot. If the honourable member for the Northern Territory believes that he can live in Brisbane and still represent his Northern Territory constituents, if my neighbours the honourable member for Deakin ( Mr Beale) and the honourable EmptyHere well outside their electorates and still represent their constituents, I have no argument with that. If I have some concern about it I am prepared to accept that their families are best served by those somewhat unusual arrangements. What I do object to is a personal attack on a member of this Government for exercising the same concern for his family. Sauce for the honourable member for the Northern Territory is not apparently sauce for the Treasurer, and yet there is no doubt about whose contribution to the nation is the more important. Australians have little time for the person who plays the man and not the ball. They have even less time for out and out hypocrites who say one thing and do another. Every time an Opposition member talks about the value of the family from now on, every Australian will be reminded that these are the people who wanted to separate the Treasurer from his family. These are the people who wanted the person carrying one of the nation's most important and demanding jobs to neglect his family. These are the people who wanted young children to grow up without their father. These are the people who put the family last in their priorities. What the Opposition hates is that a man can be a brilliant Treasurer and a good husband and father. What does the Opposition want? Do members of the Opposition want everyone to conform to their doubtful standard because they are inadequate? Do they want to encourage the break up of families of members and Ministers? Do they have no respect at all for the values of family life? Do they care so little about the responsibilities of a growing family that they want those responsibilities carried by one parent? Are they totally without shame? Unfortunately the simple answer to all those questions is yes. No pretence is too great to stick in their throats. No double standard is too disgraceful for them to defend. No mud is too dirty to be thrown, and no ditch is too slimy to deter them. One really has to have a strong stomach to sit in this House and listen to the Opposition, an Opposition whose members are incapable of producing policies that are not laughable, who substitute personal attack for their abysmal failure as policy makers, whose tactics match their characters, who plumb the depths of the political gutters and who want to rise like the phoenix from the ashes of their own incapacity.
